timestamp: Reviewed in the United States December 8, 2023
product_name: Panasonic ErgoFit RZ-B310W - True Wireless Earbuds

title: 4.0 out of 5 stars Quite impressive
author: Yan L.
content: The Panasonic ErgoFit True Wireless Earbuds with Noise Cancelling have impressed me with their exceptional sound quality and convenient features. From their sleek design to their powerful audio performance, these earbuds provide a satisfying listening experience that will elevate your music enjoyment.The first thing that caught my attention was the ergonomic design of the earbuds. They fit snugly and comfortably in my ears, thanks to the multiple sizes of ear tips included in the package. The lightweight construction ensures extended periods of use without discomfort, making them suitable for daily activities or intense workout sessions.The sound quality delivered by these earbuds is truly remarkable. The built-in noise cancelling technology effectively blocks out ambient noise, allowing you to fully immerse yourself in your favorite tunes. The audio is crisp, clear, and well-balanced, with a particular emphasis on the powerful bass response. The XBS (Extra Bass System) feature adds depth and richness to the low-end frequencies, enhancing the overall listening experience, especially for bass enthusiasts.With Bluetooth 5.3 connectivity, pairing the earbuds with my device was seamless and hassle-free. The wireless connection remained stable even when moving around, and I experienced minimal latency while watching videos or playing games. The touch controls on the earbuds provide easy access to playback controls, volume adjustment, and even voice assistant activation, making it convenient to manage your audio on the go.The included charging case is compact and sleek, serving as a secure storage solution for the earbuds while also providing additional battery life. The case's built-in battery can recharge the earbuds multiple times, ensuring that you can enjoy your music throughout the day without worrying about running out of power. The USB-C charging port offers fast charging capabilities, minimizing the downtime between listening sessions.While the Panasonic ErgoFit True Wireless Earbuds deliver excellent sound quality and convenient features, there are a few areas where they could be further improved. The battery life of the earbuds themselves could be extended, as they offer around 4-5 hours of continuous playback, which may not be sufficient for long trips or extended listening sessions without access to the charging case. Additionally, the touch controls on the earbuds can sometimes be overly sensitive, leading to accidental commands.Overall, the Panasonic ErgoFit True Wireless Earbuds with Noise Cancelling offer an impressive audio experience, combining powerful bass, effective noise cancelling, and convenient features in a compact design. Whether you're a music lover, a fitness enthusiast, or someone who appreciates wireless freedom, these earbuds deliver on their promise of immersive sound and provide great value for their price.
timestamp: Reviewed in the United States June 13, 2023
product_name: Panasonic ErgoFit RZ-B310W - True Wireless Earbuds

title: 4.0 out of 5 stars A good performer
author: WT
content: The Panasonic RZ-B310W is not currently compatible with the Panasonic Audio Connect app so you are limited to the controls available on the earbuds and there isn't an equalizer. Controls available using the touch panels on the earbuds include music control (pause, forward, backward) and sound control (ANC, ambient sound, off). Unfortunately, sound control toggles from ANC to Off to Ambient Sound. This means it takes two touches to go from ANC to Ambient Sound and I find that to be a bit annoying. I prefer going from ANC to Ambient to Off. You can also turn the buds on or off using the touch panels. The earbuds are lightweight, comfortable and fit my ears well. I can get a good seal using the included eartips and the sound isolation is very good. Construction quality is excellent as you would expect from Panasonic. The charging case is small and will easily slip into a pocket.The earbuds are tuned too bright for my liking. I use the equalizer in my music app to tune the earbuds. The bass is strong without being boomy but sounds a bit loose. The overall sound signature is V-shaped but pleasing to the ear. However, you must get a good seal or the sound is really messed up, with little bass, no midrange and shrill highs. These earbuds are not for critical listening but if you want something for casual listening while commuting or working at your desk, give these a try.Noise isolation and bass response depends on your achieving a good fit with one of the included eartips. If you can't get a good seal, the bass will be nearly non-existant and the treble will overpower everything.Active noise cancellation is better than I expected. It isn't at the level of the Sony WF-1000XM4 or Bose QuietComfort Earbuds 2 but it does reduce a significant amount of low frequency noise, like the roar of jet engines. To be honest I wasn't expecting this level of noise cancellation in a $99 earbud. It also does a fair job of reducing office noises.I don't normally use earbuds to make to take calls so I haven't checked the voice quality during calls.Overall, I'm very pleased with the RZ-B310W. I can easily recommend them as one of the best I've used under $100. A good value.
timestamp: Reviewed in the United States May 9, 2023
product_name: Panasonic ErgoFit RZ-B310W - True Wireless Earbuds

title: 3.0 out of 5 stars Fine for the Price - But I Have Quirks
author: Romain
content: Overall, I think these earbuds are good for the price point, but it has a few quirks that make using them less enjoyable.Sound Quality is its best feature. I tested them against my son's AirPods Gen 2 and my AirPod Pros Gen 1 on an iPhone via Apple Music. My go to song to test listening devices is Ray Charles "Georgia on my Mind" (mid volume). That song has a lot happening, and I can pick-up how well the device is as letting you hear all the details. I thought the Panasonic sounded better than the AirPod, and it held its own against the AirPod Pro. Had I played other songs, I think the Pro would win outright because of Spatial Audio features. For added fun, I listen to the track with a wired Beats earbud (lighting cord), and that beat all 3 of them.Ergonomics is Terrible. As others have mentioned, just to get it out of the case is a challenge, if you have larger fingers. When you take it out of your ears, it still plays. That is not necessarily a bad thing, but worth nothing. The case is nice looking but it does not have a sturdy feel. I case see it cracking with a moderate fall to the ground.Software and Other Quirks makes it hard to love. To start, there was no feedback on the case to tell you when it was fully charged, charging the case or charging the ear buds. Same goes with low battery. I could not make out when I needed to charge it, other than waiting for it to not play or connect. Perhaps the app is suppose to help with that? With a good app, it probably would be manageable.It's a very possessive device. As mentioned, I have multiple buds. If I start using the Panasonics, and decide to switch to another device, the Panasonics kept trying to jump back in, even when the buds were in the case. I don't know if I got a bad one or what, but a few times I had to move it away from my phone to get it to not try to take over.If it will be your only bluetooth listening device, and you don't plan on using the buttons, I think it would be fine. For me, I am already slotting the Panasonics as my TV at night device or another dedicated source to avoid it getting confused.
timestamp: Reviewed in the United States May 17, 2023
product_name: Panasonic ErgoFit RZ-B310W - True Wireless Earbuds

title: 3.0 out of 5 stars Touch controls are difficult to use and don't work with Android phone
author: Olivia
content: These headphones have some positives, but in general I don't think they are worth the money. You can get better earbuds for cheaper than this.To start with, the things I like about them: the fit. I like that they are angled into my ears, and stay in very securely. They come with different headphone tips, although the default ones were just fine for me. I've used these while running and don't slip around or start to fall out.I think the sound is decent -- not great, but not terrible. The bass is well balanced. I also use these for video calls and people report they can hear me well. In video calls, other people's voices sound slightly harsh, which I don't love. But they are definitely servicable sound. If you're really into audio balancing, you probably won't like these, though.The noise cancelling is also somewhat mediocre. I can kinda tell it's doing something, but when people are talking nearby or my dogs bark elsewhere in my house, I can hear it. They don't have the kind of noise cancelling where you put on and remove your headphones and can really notice the difference the noise cancelling makes.The thing I like the least about these are the touch controls. They are really tough to get to work and they don't work beyond play/pause with my Android phone (Pixel 7 pro). When I use these paired to my computer, I have to really focus on how I tap and where exactly my finger lands to get the controls to respond. If I'm wearing these out while running, I have to stop running and hold still to get the play/pause to work. Otherwise, if I'm paired with my phone, I can't get it to advance/repeat track or change volume. I tried downloading the Panasonic devices app, thinking that might be the issue, but I can't get that to work at all (it never pairs with the headphones and is stuck in a loop).In the end, these aren't worth the money to me. I'd rather spend more for a more solid product that works, like Airpods or GalaxyBuds, or go for a cheaper pair that might not have the nice fit, but has more functional touch controls.
timestamp: Reviewed in the United States June 4, 2023
product_name: Panasonic ErgoFit RZ-B310W - True Wireless Earbuds

title: 4.0 out of 5 stars Punchy sound and a comfortable fit
author: expatbrit
content: These are impressive earbuds that do a lot of things right and only come up short in 2 areas.The sound is bass heavy, as expected from the XBS feature, and it can produce some really meaty lows, but this can be dialed down with a good equalizer.Out of the box they sounded a little underwhelming but they improved steadily after a dozen hours or so. I still prefer the more enveloping sound of my Soundpeats buds, but these are more than acceptable, especially with a high bit rate streaming service.There's plenty of volume on tap and the Bluetooth range is a little more than 30 feet, about par for the course across similar products.Panasonic is always good at proving clear instructions, but only the quick start guide is useful here, with picture based instructions. The little booklet offers safety advice in multiple languages, an odd inclusion.One thing these RZs excel at is comfort. Once you find the right rubber tips (3 sizes included) then they stay put, some of the best I've tried. Even talking and eating couldn't shift them, a rare find in my experience. These would make excellent buds for the gym.Battery life is a key selling point on the box, and it's proving correct so far; with minimal charging and extended use, no 'battery low' warning yet. Charging is via a USB C type port, widely becoming the standard these days.One downside is the fiddly shape of the bud and the case, it's all too smooth with no real area to grip, so getting them out of the case takes practice. The touch controls are also slow to respond but work well enough once you get the right zone at the top of the stalk.There's no noise cancelling to speak of (I have tested them on a plane) but they don't claim to have it, so that's OK.For the user looking for a good all-round set of wireless buds, from a household name that will almost certainly be around to honor a warranty in years to come, these are a solid value.
timestamp: Reviewed in the United States June 1, 2023
product_name: Panasonic ErgoFit RZ-B310W - True Wireless Earbuds

title: 4.0 out of 5 stars An affordable option that deliver good results on sound quality and functionality
author: Kevin
content: Although I am not a power-user when it comes to wireless earbuds, I am picky when it comes to comfort, and most importantly, sound quality. For may years now I have used AirPods and AirPods Pro models. I have generally been very satisfied with them, with the latter being a little less comfortable for me than I would prefer, and sound quality of both being on the above average side. And as far as functionality, they have worked pretty much flawlessly for me.When I saw these Panasonic ErgoFit earbuds, they seemed to boast the features that I tend to look for ‚Äì good sound, Bluetooth connectivity, noise cancelling, a portable charging case ‚Äì and of course, good sound quality with good base.My overall impression of the Panasonic‚Äôs is on the good side of the spectrum. As far as sound quality, in my opinion, I have found them to be on par with my AirPod Pros, and better than my standard AirPods, but that should be expected given that the Panasonics seal in your ears just like the AirPod Pros do. I‚Äôve also found the noise cancelling and ambient sound modes to work very well. I would however give the edge to the Pros on ambient sound mode. The Panasonics have something of a white-noise in the background when using ambient sound mode, and it is noticeable when you are not playing music.On phone calls, I can hear very clearly, and based on my testing, callers can also hear me very clearly, so the microphones do a very good job on phone calls. I would say that they seem to pick up a little more ambient noise than my AirPods, and callers can hear more background noise when speaking to me. But overall, unless you are doing something noisy, they work fine.As far as fitment goes, I‚Äôve found these to be bulkier than my Airpods and AirPod Pros. I would also say they are just slightly less comfortable than the Pros as well. But, given the activities that I use ‚Äúear-sealing‚Äù earbuds for, like jogging, mowing the lawn and working outside, I find them to be more than comfortable enough. Comfort is very subjective, so these may or may not be a good option for you.As to overall build quality, the Panasonic earbuds themselves feel solid and well made. The case on the other hand has something of an empty feeling to it, unlike the Apple cases which feel sturdy and well made. But regardless, the case works just fine, which ultimately is what matters.I have noticed that the Bluetooth connection with the Panasonics is not as resilient as it is with either pair my AirPods. In an open and unobstructed environment, the reliability of the connection, and the range of the connection is perfectly fine. However, if you introduce obstructions and if you change the orientation of your body, you will start losing the connection. If you keep your phone on your person this should not be a problem, but I like to place my phone down somewhere safe while I am mowing or if I am working on projects outdoors, and I have been annoyed by the tendency of the connection to drop more often than the AirPods do.So overall, what do I think about the Panasonic ErgoFit earbuds? Well, I like that you can get good sound quality while listening or speaking - and out of earbuds for under $100 dollars as not everyone has the money to purchase more expensive options. While the Panasonics lack some of the refinement of more expensive units, they put out good sound and offer the convenience of a portable charging case like their more expensive cousins. For working out, working outdoors, or just working around the house while jamming some tunes, I see these as an affordable option that shouldn't disappoint you, particularly as these are a value item in my opinion. I do feel like they could do a little bit better on the price though - $80 seems like an attractive figure, and the lower the cost gets under that $100 price point, the more attractive these Panasonics become.
timestamp: Reviewed in the United States May 19, 2023
product_name: Panasonic ErgoFit RZ-B310W - True Wireless Earbuds

title: 4.0 out of 5 stars Pretty great headphones.
author: Elizabeth Mays
content: I unintentionally tested these out under some of the best conditions possible: a room full of teachers at their professional development at the beginning of a school year. The sound was amazing, and I was able to focus on what I was doing and what I was listening to instead of all the chaos around me... but the sound from all the other teachers talking and joking around me was not completely canceled. It was more like hearing them from underwater: I was aware of the sound, the tempo or cadence of people speaking, but couldn't make out what they were saying and a couple of times I had to figure out that someone was talking to me because they were trying to make eye contact. I could hear them speaking, but could not make out the words.They are very comfortable, and they last for a long time, and I think they are a good level of noise limiting, but not quite canceling.
timestamp: Reviewed in the United States August 16, 2023
product_name: Panasonic ErgoFit RZ-B310W - True Wireless Earbuds

title: 4.0 out of 5 stars I would order these again!
author: Customer Review
content: I ordered these for myself because my old earbuds stopped charging. These are a little bit too big for my ears but I have small ear canals. I would say for most folks these are going to be a nice¬†and snug fit. They are comfortable and I don't even notice they are in my ears. I must say the sound quality is very good to excellent and the noise canceling really does block out noises in your immediate environment. These are the most expensive¬†earbuds¬†I have owned so far and I am not an expert at listening to music with earbuds. They were easy to connect with my Android Note 9 phone. The case has a built-in battery that recharges the earbuds as needed. A USB-C cord is provided and does a great job of fast charging (the webpage states a 15-minute charge gives 60 minutes of¬†playback). I don't use them often but I would say I can use them both for roughly 5 hours plus on a single charge. The instructions state you can get 26 hours by using the charging case. The quality is very good and I am happy with these and the price is great.
timestamp: Reviewed in the United States August 16, 2023
product_name: Panasonic ErgoFit RZ-B310W - True Wireless Earbuds

title: 2.0 out of 5 stars Disappointing
author: Rob M.
content: I have owned and tested dozens of true wireless earbuds over the past few years.I really wanted to like these earbuds, but they have too many flaws. There are better choices out there at this or lower price points.Pros- Small, pocketable case- Good build quality. Solid Panasonic reputation.- Very comfortable "Ergofit"- Minimal in-ear adjustment required after insertion. They stay in place pretty well for non-winged earbuds, but do require infrequent adjustments in my wonky ears.- Sound quality is very good, even without EQing. Balanced. Good "XBS" bass, good treble. Compared to Soundcore Liberty 3 Pro, they rate 8/10 on sound.Cons- No wireless charging- A little awkward to get in and out of the case- No app support, which means no firmware updates to potentially improve them over time.- No app means no control customization.- No app means no EQ unless you use a 3rd-part EQ app like Wavelet, XEQ, or your music player's built-in EQ.- Cannot control volume from the earbuds, aside from summoning the digital assistant and asking it to turn the volume down. Cumbersome. Faster to just do it on your phone.- Controls are just OK. Sometimes you have to tap more than once to get them to register. And they seemed to respond more when I tapped below the visible sensor area than on it, but that's probably something I could adjust to in time.- ANC - The noise cancelling is just OK. It does work, and there is a marked difference between Off, Transparent Mode, and Noise Cancelling Mode. But it is not nearly as good as the Pixel Buds Pro, Liberty 3 Pro, or Earfun Free Pro 2.- Bluetooth connection stability. They have Bluetooth 5.3, as does my Pixel 7 phone. Despite un-pairing and re-pairing several times with my phone, they would frequently lose pairing, then re-pair. Sometimes they would not re-pair or re-connect without putting them back in the case and pulling them back out. During playback, they would have several very short interruptions or glitches per song. Very quick, like a record skipping, but still quite noticeable and aggravating. Sometimes when grasping the stem to adjust their fit in my ear, they lose connection and say "pairing". If buds can't stay connected, they are useless. I don't have these problems with other buds.- As is true with most buds, if they lose seal the sound quality degrades a lot. No bass, shrill treble, and no ANC because of outside sound leakage. You have to adjust them to get the seal and the bass back. But there's a 50/50 chance they'll lose connection when you grasp the stem to adjust.- Phone voice quality is just OK. The clarity is fine, but the volume is quiet. Callers have a hard time hearing me unless I speak quite loudly.I don't feel these buds are worth $100. They have a solid Panasonic brand name & build quality, but they offer too little for the money. A $50-65 price point is more realistic for these buds.Soundcore Liberty 3 Pro list for $169 but are frequently discounted to $129 or even $99.Earfun Free Pro 2 or Air Pro 3 are less than $99.Pixel Buds Pro list for $199 but are often on sale for $149.I would choose any of those over these Panasonics.
timestamp: Reviewed in the United States May 12, 2023
product_name: Panasonic ErgoFit RZ-B310W - True Wireless Earbuds

title: 4.0 out of 5 stars Lots of bass, ANC, ambient mode, not the most comfortable.
author: Avid83
content: These Panasonic earbuds are awesome for listening to music with deep bass. They connect easily to your iPhone or PC via Bluetooth and have a stable connection. They come with different sizes of rubber tips, but they could fit better in your ears. Maybe longer stems would help. Fortunately, these are lightweight, but not the most compact design.The earbuds have some cool features like noise cancelling, ambient mode, and a low latency mode called ‚Äúgame mode.‚Äù You can turn on game mode by tapping the earbuds 5 times quickly. It makes games and videos in sync, but sometimes it‚Äôs prone to dropouts. Active noise cancelling works well at reducing outside sounds, but also introduces some low but noticeable noise. I didn‚Äôt try exercising with these, but they do have an IPX4 water resistant rating.The touch sensors on these earbuds are not very responsive and have a delay. You have to get used to them and find the right spot to tap. You can't control the volume with them, but you can do other things like skip tracks, pause, answer calls, and use voice assistants. The earbuds don't fall out of your ears, but they do slip a bit over time and have to be readjusted. Battery life seems good, and the charging case uses a USB-C connection, although the included cable fits unusually tight.Although not perfect, these earbuds have a lot of modern features like ANC and a USB-C connection to charge the case. I would recommend them, but the fit may not be the best depending on the shape of your ears.
timestamp: Reviewed in the United States May 8, 2023
product_name: Panasonic ErgoFit RZ-B310W - True Wireless Earbuds

title: 5.0 out of 5 stars Very nice
author: Jamwls79
content: This is the first pair of buds I have had where the bar hangs from the ear. They do feel different then my other buds, I got used to them quickly. These have decent sound and I'd say the battery last around 3 to 4 hours of straight play time which isn't bad. I only where one at a time, so when one dies I charge it while using the other. The cas gives a few charges and fits real nice into my front pants pocket. For the price, these are pretty nice.
timestamp: Reviewed in the United States November 22, 2023
product_name: Panasonic ErgoFit RZ-B310W - True Wireless Earbuds

title: 4.0 out of 5 stars These are ok, the range isn't great
author: M.S.
content: For these earbuds to be on the higher end for price, they're not that impressive. They do have good sound, I'll give them that. The battery like is average at about 6 hours. And the case doesn't work on a wireless charger, only when plugged. Wireless charging isn't a big deal, but it's always a plus especially for earbuds at this price point. And there are cheaper options that offer these features.The connection range is not good if I'm being honest. Infact it may be the worst of any earbuds I've tried. If I leave out of the room the sound immediately starts getting choppy and eventually disconnects. And the rooms in my house aren't large. Also, sometimes it will randomly disconnect then reconnect even though I'm right in front of my phone. I'm not sure why this happens.The mic quality is good. I haven't had any issues while on calls. Overall it's a decent pair of earbuds. I would however consider some other options before getting these.
timestamp: Reviewed in the United States May 29, 2023
product_name: Panasonic ErgoFit RZ-B310W - True Wireless Earbuds

title: 3.0 out of 5 stars Low on volume, awkward controls, but alright earbuds.
author: opal
content: I have a different set of earbuds that I'm pretty happy with, but they keep falling out of my ears and the shape gets uncomfortable after an hour or so of use, so I wanted to try this style out. Since Panasonic is a brand I grew up around, I had high hopes for these earbuds.These paired easily with my phone, and they're comfortable on my ears for their whole two and a half hour battery life.These earbuds are a pain to get out of the case, even with my small hands and somewhat long nails.The controls are AWFUL. They're difficult to master, rarely react the same way twice except to pause when I'm trying to skip, I cannot skip songs nor activate the ANC, and there's very little about the controls in the instruction booklet aside from a leaflet with mostly pictures- the other booklet is a European warranty that lacks a language that I can understand. I have no clue what the picture means for how to activate the ANC, so I gave up on that front. I can just barely get these to answer calls, so I don't bother. I use my phone's controls over the ones on these earbuds, they're so difficult to work with.I have to turn off my phone's bluetooth to disengage these earbuds from it.The volume on these is not stellar- at their max, I'm just barely satisfied with the volume, even when using VLC. Sometimes I want louder music to drown out construction work and the industrial-level banging at the nearby oil well- these cannot do that.However I do find that the sound is overall reasonably balanced, and the strength of the bass is adequate- but not great. The highs and mids are so-so: nothing to complain about, but the mids get muddy in certain ranges, and the highs are a tad too sharp at certain tones. I think that these are fine for casual use, but could be lacking for audiophiles.I can definitely say that I've used worse, but there's better earbuds out there.For a pair of earbuds from a such a well-known brand, these miss the mark. However for a pair of earbuds that let me listen to background music comfortably, these do the job fairly.Panasonic ErgoFit True Wireless Earbuds, Bluetooth 5.3 in Ear Headphones with XBS Powerful Bass, Charging Case ‚Äì RZ-B110W
timestamp: Reviewed in the United States May 22, 2023
product_name: Panasonic ErgoFit RZ-B310W - True Wireless Earbuds

title: 3.0 out of 5 stars My favorite bud-style head phone so far! BUT one died after little use.
author: Joseph Melcher
content: Update of July 13, 2023: Despite my really positive review below, after only a few uses, one day, one of the buds simply stopped functioning. They are fully charged and no amount of fiddling has enabled me to get it working again. The one pairs automatically; the other just stays silent.First of all, these are truly noise-canceling. When you activate this function, there is a slight, but notable reduction in the ambient noise. Most importantly, they have excellent sound quality, with the best bass response I've noted in testing several of these types of buds. It boomsThe mid-range and treble range are also well balanced. They handle nicely and the controls are quite intuitive. I've not had a chance to test their battery life because I never listen more than an hour or so and then they get topped off in their storage case, which I just recharge periodically.
timestamp: Reviewed in the United States May 14, 2023
product_name: Panasonic ErgoFit RZ-B310W - True Wireless Earbuds

title: 5.0 out of 5 stars Nice ear buds with great sound
author: Norman White
content: After receiving the buds I tried to attach the correct sized rubber pieces on to them and WOW was that difficult. They came off without too much issue but getting the new ones on...very tough.They didn't come off easy enough to worry about them popping off during normal wear and use but easy enough that I wasn't worried about tearing them.Pairing them was smooth and they quickly pair and disconnect when taken out and put away.The case is a nice slick black case that fits in the pocket and carges the buds nicely. I only wish there were covers for the case like with the Apple ones so that I can attach them to my lanyard like I do the Apple ones.I use these mainly as my work ear buds while away from the desk and the sound is perfect, I can be heard from other parties loud and clear and the volume on the buds for me works.They feel like they are about to slip out of my ears some times but they don't so i think I'm just used to using the AirPods where they fit inside more. Either that or I need to actually move to a smaller silicone piece.Been using these for some time now and after the initial full charge I haven't had to charge the case yet. I'd say that I've been using them for at least 3 to 4 hours per week and it's been at least three or four weeks since I have charged the case.Overall I'd give them a good rating on almost every aspect. They do cancel out some of the noise but not all of it unless the volume is turned up all the way. They don't crack or hiss when listening to quiet conversations and the little bit that I tested them with music it sounds like they would be perfect listening to everything from Bach to Black Sabbath.Highly recomend.
timestamp: Reviewed in the United States July 5, 2023

title: 4.0 out of 5 stars Typical earbuds.
author: Denise
content: 4 stars only because these are Panasonic brand and they fit really good. Sound is great but as with most lower end ear buds you have to turn your device up to about 80% volume to get the best sound. I have decided that over/on ear headphones are your best bet for good sound. I even tried a volume/equalizer booster to see if that affected the sound. It helped a little. Sound out of 10 to 12mm drivers just isn't that great especially if the earbuds are of the budget end of the spectrum. If this is your earbud range buy these if not and you can afford better buy better.

content: The earbuds do everything it says. Touch functions work, earbuds themselves do the job if you're not picky about audio quality (not super cheap quality but not high quality for sure). If someone is talking to you WITH no sound playing, you'll be able to understand them somewhat okay. For me, I wouldn't use this function at all. Case and earbuds are made of hard plastic, does not feel premium in the slightest, if anything really cheap feeling.TLDR: Earbuds work, but are mediocre for the price. timestamp: Reviewed in the United States June 27, 2023

title: 5.0 out of 5 stars Panasonic does not disappoint! Amazing sound in a budget earbuds set!
author: WeAreGoingSomewhere
content: Wow, these are impressive! The sound quality is absolutely comparable to the best stuff out there. Soundcore Liberty 3 Pro, 1MORE EVO, Soundpeats Capsule 3 Pro, OnePlus Buds Pro 2 and you can pick your favorite model of Bose or Sony. These do not stay behind, not even an inch. Excellent sound staging, beautiful instrument separation. The highs are detailed, crisp, wide expanded and they never sound harsh - amazing. Bass is deep and wonderfully real sounding, not overwhelming, just right. Mids are... well, they're there just where they need to be for 95% of people (more or less) to absolutely LOVE this sound signature.ERGONOMICS: feels like they are copied from some other earbuds but it's not a bad thing. The fit is fantastic, they are lightweight and the touch controls while nowhere near the awesome convenience of Edifier work well enough!AESTHETICS: I like how this set looks. Actually, I love it. Understated, Panasonic logo on the side. Perfect!CASE: this is the weakest point. Another example of pointless vertical case design that makes it super annoyingly difficult to take the earbuds out. WHY?!?!? A frustrating kink in what otherwise could be a super high rated set of earbuds. I forgive this beause of how good they sound but people with thicker fingers will want to throw this against the wall.APP SUPPORT: so far couldn't get the Panasonic connect app to work (on iOS) so I will update the review when I have some success here.MIC/PHONE CALLS: haven't tried yet because I keep listening to my favorirte songs and for now don't want to stop haha (will update the review soon - for now just wanted the world to know these sound absolutely AMAZING!).

title: 4.0 out of 5 stars Light, efficient, easy to utilize its functions
author: Customer
content: Connects quickly and STAYS connected. However. The music sound quality is among the worst I've heard (sound engineer) and cannot be mitigated by software. I.e. running the media through a processor such as Poweramp equalizer will only distort the sound. These drivers are simply not made for accurate sound reproduction from media. Voices: absolutely. Call quality is excellent. But that is it. Concerned about construction as they are remarkably light. The case is an exercise in patience as there are both metal and plasyic prongs that must line up. Force it and the buds will be rendered useless an irreparable. Clearly, no expense was spared to install good drivers (speakers) or a solid structure nor a painless way to dock to buds.None at all.Probably leftovers from a Chinese manufacturer that changes its ridiculous nonsensical names bianually.Battery life is excellent.

title: 1.0 out of 5 stars First ever disappointment with Panasonic
author: M. Hoffman
content: I am 73 years of age and have been purchasing Panasonic products since I was in college. Transistor radios, boom boxes, Technics components, telephones, plasma tv (still working more than 10 years old), etc, etc. Most recently I purchased two pairs of Wings bluetooth earbuds. They worked well, BUT their life seemed relatively short. I am still attempting to determine what a reasonable life is for bluetooth earbuds. Now, I purchased these "true wireless" (?) earbuds twice. The first pair did not charge. The second pair which I kept has many, many problems with the sensors, maintaining bluetooth connection, etc. When they work, they work well, but it was a full two weeks until the full volume kicked in and that occurred unexpectedly after multiple beeping, changes of volume, cutout, noise setting, etc, etc. Last night was the first time they worked relatively flawlessly until I arrived back home after a two hour walk. They began cutting out again. Considering that I could have bought innumerable cheaper bluetooth earbuds of other manufacturers and far less expensive, it is disappointing. I sincerely hope this is not a continuing problem with Panasonic products. Their customer service is also difficult. As an example, although the directions say you should use ONLY the power cord supplied for charging, the customer service said I could use any generic USB C cord. He had no explanation for the directions. They also fall out of your ears. I am at the end of my rope with these things. Going back. I reset them with the app, explored all attempts to remedy the problems, but they are just too frustrating.

title: 5.0 out of 5 stars Movement focused TW earbuds from Beats with great sound
author: Ant
content: My pair of Beats Powerbeats Pros were starting to die out on me. I had purchased them secondhand so I wasn‚Äôt too upset, but I needed a replacement. I decided to get a new pair of true wireless earbuds this time around.After doing some research on the top recommended workout focused true wireless earbuds, it came down to the Beats Fit Pro and the Beats Studio Buds.Ultimately I decided on the more expensive of the two, thinking it would be worth the extra cost. I got them on a sale that was running here which makes it even better. My use case for them would be for gym workouts such as jogging/walking and lifting, and also for casual use at work and home.I‚Äôve had this pair for a little over 1 year and 6 months. I have purchased Apple care + for them but have not had to use it.EXPERIENCE:The sound on these, personally, is really enjoyable! The noise cancelling and transparency mode work so well.If I‚Äôm at the gym and don‚Äôt want to hear the other people making noise with their machines or the running of treadmills? Turn on noise cancelling and have music on. In a snap, the outside noises seem to be gone.At work and don‚Äôt want to miss a phone call?Turn on transparency mode and you‚Äôre free to hear sounds around you. Even better with just one earbud in, too.The mic quality on calls seems to be passable, people seem to hear me fine.*Small note: there is a tiny rip in the silicone/plastic on the right bud‚Äôs button near the bottom. I suspect this is from wearing them when going to bed sometimes. I usually wake up and find them out of my ears. There are times where they‚Äôre still in my ears, but I tend to move around during when asleep.OTHER THOUGHTS:I really like the wing tips on the earbuds, they stay in my ears perfectly. Sure, there was some soreness in my ears in the beginning, but my ears got used to it pretty fast. Also, the ear tip size helps a lot. Make sure you try all the included sizes to really figure out which one is most comfortable.There is definitely a learning curve on inserting the earbuds into your ears. Once you get the method of inserting them smoothly and creating the right seal, they are more enjoyable. Look at one of the animations in the earbud‚Äôs description for reference.Plus, the sage grey colorway just looks dope. Wish there was a lava red colorway available like the Powerbeats Pro.These work great with my iPhone and connected to my PC. Can‚Äôt speak for performance on an Android device. I am perfectly happy with this purchase!(Pictured is the earbuds, with an aftermarket cover on the case to protect from accidental damage)

title: 4.0 out of 5 stars Good Apple Ecosystem Option for Running
author: C. Godby
content: Before buying the Beats Fit Pro, I've owned the PowerBeats Pro and AirPods Pro 2. I'm a runner that wants an Apple ecosystem option that has decent sound quality and won't fall out of my ear. After two runs and a trip to the gym, I'm happy with them so far. Out of the three options above, I consider them the best option for running. My quick thoughts on each:The PowerBeats Pro has been out for two or three years now and I'm surprised there hasn't been an updated model. They're good earbuds for runners...when they work. And the when they work part is infuriating. The earbuds have to line up perfectly with the charging connections in the case or they won't charge. I can't tell you how many times I've gone to use them and found one fully charged and the other dead. There was even a potential class action lawsuit filed against Apple on that (search for it). When they work, the PowerBeats Pro are solid because they hook around your ear. You can have confidence when you run they're not going to fall out - I never had an issue in the two years or so I owned them with that. There is also a physical button for changing songs and pausing the music and a rocker for changing the volume, which is convenient. Cons: sound quality is ho hum in my opinion - it never feels like they secure cleanly in your ear. Also, there's no wireless charging or noise cancellation. Oh, and of course the infuriating charging issues. I would not buy the PowerBeats Pro again for that reason.On to the AirPods Pro 2. These earbuds have better sound quality in my opinion than both the PowerBeats Pro and Beats Fit Pro. The noise cancellation meaningfully improved from gen 1 to gen 2. There's wireless charging and a speaker installed in the case so you can ping them using the "find my" app on your iPhone. For day to day use around the home or office, these earbuds are awesome. However, at least for me, they're not for running. While more secure than the regular AirPods, they still fall out of my ears sometimes and that certainly applies to running. If you buy after market rubber hooks, Air Pods Pro 2 (and 1) will stay secure when running and provide a good experience (they don't fall out). That said, having to attach the rubber hooks each time you go to run is a pain in the butt.The Beats Fit Pro makes some compromises, but in my opinion it's the best option for runners based on my limited experience so far. The rubber wing tips ensure that the Beats Fit Pro has a secure fit in your ear. They've felt secure running and haven't fallen out in my experience so far. There's a physical button for changing the song, activating noise cancellation, and pausing the music. Versus the PowerBeats Pro, there's no rubber hook so they're not as secure and there's no volume rocker. However, they do have noise cancellation and fit more snugly in your ear. As a result, I think the sound quality is a little better than the PowerBeats Pro, but not as good as the AirPods Pro 2. On the downside, I think the case feels cheap compared to the AirPods, there's no wireless charging, and there's no speaker on the case for the "find my" app. In addition, the case charges using USB C instead of lightning (btw, it's a USB C to USB C cable included with them and there's no power brick included). USB C is coming to iPhone and I believe is already on iPad, but it's irritating that it has a USB C cable instead of lightning when your life revolves around lightning cables.In short, avoid the Powerbeats Pro - the charging issue is a design flaw and will lead to frustration over time. The AirPods Pro 2 are awesome, but they're not a good option for running since they will fall out of many people's ears. The Beats Fit Pro makes compromises, but in my experience so far its the best Apple ecosystem earbud for running.
timestamp: Reviewed in the United States February 8, 2023

title: 5.0 out of 5 stars Best wireless noise cancelling earbuds I have used so far
author: theInternational
content: I am a long-time user of the Bose QuietComfort 20 Acoustic Noise Cancelling Headphones. These are my favorite noise cancelling option to use while taking walks. I like to listen to audio books while walking and the QuietComfort 20 are superb for this use. I also like to use a noise cancelling option while listening to audio books and podcasts in the car, especially because my car does not contain road noise well. I decided I would like to have a second QuietComfort 20 reserved for use in my car. An additional advantage to having a second one is if anything happens to the one I walk with, I'll have a backup. But, unfortunately, Bose discontinued the QuietComfort 20 forcing me to have to find another option for use in the car.I first purchased the wireless Bose QuietComfort Earbuds. But I found much to dislike about them. They feel heavy in the ears; the buds themselves just feel heavier and less comfortable than the QuietComfort 20 Headphones. I also disliked that every time I put the Bose QuietComfort Earbuds into my ears they speak to me telling me they are trying to connect to my device and also reporting battery state. I found this incredibly annoying. Another thing I hugely disliked was that there is an uncomfortable "boom boom" sensation as I walk with them in. I wear Vibram FiveFinger shoes and do not walk with a heavy gait. I do not get this "boom boom" sensation when walking with the QuietComfort 20 headphones. I also disliked how big the Bose QuietComfort Earbuds' case was. I disliked how the Bose QuietComfort Earbuds sometimes felt like they weren't secure in my ears and when I would try to adjust their stability I would accidentally change the noise cancellation setting. On two occasions, an uncomfortable high pitched sound emitted from one of the buds; it only lasted for a couple seconds but it was annoying. I tried using the Bose QuietComfort Earbuds for a month and never could bring myself to like them, so I returned them. I now have a strong dislike for Bose, primarily because they discontinued my beloved QuietComfort 20 Headphones. But up until recently, I was a huge Bose fan.I purchased Apple AirPods Pro. I immediately fell in love with the H1 chip operation. But I didn't like the color white. I also didn't like the stalk that extends down. But I started using them thinking I had found my noise cancelling option for the car. And although the AirPods Pro delivered some "boom boom" sensation while walking, it was much much better than the Bose QuietComfort Earbuds. Then I started to become aware of a huge problem with the AirPods Pro. They would not stay in my ears. I would place them in ear, hear the noise cancellation activate and then in time the noise cancellation would turn off because one of the pods had pushed out of my ear enough to cause the noise cancellation function to disengage. I found myself constantly having to push them into my ear in an effort to keep them from pushing out. A couple times they plain fell out of my ears. I consulted instructionals on how to properly insert them into my ears for proper fit. I also did the fit test and passed the test indicating I had good seal. Only the seal wouldn't last and the pods would eventually push out of my ears. So I had to return the AirPods Pro because they wouldn't stay in my ears.I purchased some non noise cancelling earbuds thinking that a passive seal would be enough, but I found a number of problems with this option. I didn't like shoving thing way into my ear. Not only was it a little uncomfortable, but I also wondered about the sanitariness of touching (e.g., foam inserts) prior to shoving them into my ear. Maybe this could lead to ear infection? Also, the amount of sound isolation was too good which diminished my situational awareness while walking and/or driving. So passive noise block earbuds weren't solving my use need.I was worried there was no option for the car and I would not have a backup to my beloved QuietComfort 20 headphones. I really wish I could buy another pair of QuietComfort 20 headphones just to have a backup for the future. After delaying and delaying, I decided to go to the trouble to try one last option for the car: the Beats Fit Pro. Eureka!The Beats Fit Pro are fantastic! They have the H1 chip, which is awesome. They fit and feel way better than the Bose QuietComfort Earbuds and are super secure in my ears, unlike the AirPods Pro. The Beats Fit Pro feel so light to wear. I can wear them all day and there is no discomfort. They also have a button to cycle through the noise cancellation options, which I like a lot better than the tapping that was needed on the Bose QuietComfort Earbuds. I also like the button press on the Beats Fit Pro better than the stalk-squeeze on the AirPods Pro.The one edge that I might say the Bose QuietComfort Earbuds have over the others is the noise cancellation. The Bose QuietComfort Earbuds arguably provide more intense noise cancellation that results in more of a bass presence and a sense that the content being played is closer to you. However, there is a cost to this that I don't think is worth it. The biggest cost for me was the "boom boom" sensation while walking. I don't know exactly what is to blame for this but it completely ruins the earbuds for what I want to use them for. I found the fit and noise cancellation of the Beats Fit Pro to be better suited to my needs.I wrote this to help others in their quest to find the earbuds that work best for them. I strongly recommend giving the Beats Fit Pro a try. I like them a lot. I think many others will too.ADDENDUM (added 2022-NOV): My beloved wired Bose QuietComfort 20 Acoustic Noise Cancelling Headphones stopped working a few weeks ago. I purchased the wired Bose Headphones many, many years ago and used them a lot, so it was not unexpected. Fortunately, the Beats Fit Pro have been able to replace the wired Headphones for my daily walks. The Beats Fit Pro have minimal "boom boom" sensation while stepping/walking. Although the Beats Fit Pro have more "boom boom" than the wired Bose Headphones, the "boom boom" is minimal and much, much better than offered by the wireless Bose QuietComfort Earbuds. I have been using the Beats Fit Pro in cold weather lately and discovered that the physical side button on the Beats Fit Pro works fantastically when wearing a hat. For example, if I am wearing a thick knit winter hat, I can still activate the side button on the Beats Fit Pro by pushing on the outside of the hat. This can't be done with a touch-operation "button" like found on the Bose QuietComfort Earbuds. The AirPods Pro "button" might be more difficult to operate with a hat on too. So if you are intending to use earbuds under a hat or hood, Beats Fit Pro will give you the advantage of still having full, easy use of the side button for play/pause operation from outside the hat.

title: 5.0 out of 5 stars Compared to 4 other Earbuds...
author: Connor
content: I bought these earbuds along with 4 other pairs, with the intent of comparing them over a couple weeks and returning all but my favorite. Here were the results:Beats Fit Pro - https://www.amazon.com/dp/B09JL65GNM?psc=1&ref=ppx_yo2ov_dt_b_product_detailsPros ‚Äì These buds had some great base, and the wingtip gave them a fit that made them refuse to fall out of my ears. But the best feature? Physical ‚Äúclicky‚Äù buttons on each one of the buds. You press in and hear/feel the click, rather than relying on a touchscreen-like feature. No need to guess if you tapped them once or twice, you will know.Cons ‚Äì The wingtip gives a very sturdy fit, but not the most comfortable. I wouldn‚Äôt recommend to anyone with smaller ears. The noise canceling was solid, but nothing special. And this may be picky, but I didn‚Äôt care for most of the color schemes available. I prefer my earbuds to be hard to notice, and even the black ones have a bright red letter ‚Äúb‚Äù in the middle.Beats Studio Buds - https://www.amazon.com/dp/B096SV8SJG?psc=1&ref=ppx_yo2ov_dt_b_product_detailsPros ‚Äì Very comfortable with the same great physically ‚Äúclicky‚Äù buttons as the Beats Fit Pro. Noise canceling seemed slightly better than average. Great base. Classic look.Cons ‚Äì Tested during a workout, a little bit of sweat had these sliding right out of my ear. The case for these earbuds also was the flimsiest of any I had tested, with a very weak hinge that I was scared of breaking off within the 2 weeks of using.Samsung Galaxy Buds Pro - https://www.amazon.com/dp/B08MWZHHKP?psc=1&ref=ppx_yo2ov_dt_b_product_detailsPros ‚Äì A neat feature that I noticed only in these earbuds was that it had noise amplification as well as noise cancelation. With one swipe in the app, the surrounding sound was actually louder and clearer than it would be without the earbuds in. Great if you are hard of hearing, or just enjoy snooping on conversations out of reach.Cons ‚Äì Similar to the Beats Studio Buds, these didn‚Äôt stay in during a workout. They were usable, but every 10 minutes I found myself pushing them back into my ear. And this is an opinion, but these are the ugliest earbuds out of the bunch. The shiny black gleam made it look like a large beetle was hanging out in my ear. No visible brand placement either, which makes them appear cheap and generic rather than the quality Samsung they are.Samsung Galaxy Buds Live - https://www.amazon.com/dp/B09TBM1L3S?psc=1&ref=ppx_yo2ov_dt_b_product_detailsPros ‚Äì Cost effective! I added these to the test group because of the unique shape, and for that they are worth giving a try. If you have small ears and do not like the rubber insert that is standard in most other earbuds, these may be perfect for you.Cons ‚Äì Poor fit for large ears. These were tested the least of all of the buds, because the fit was so bad for my ear shape that they wouldn‚Äôt stay in if I turned my head too fast.Bose QuietComfort - https://www.amazon.com/dp/B08C4KWM9T?psc=1&ref=ppx_yo2ov_dt_b_product_detailsPros ‚Äì Bose noise canceling is unmatched. If your primary use for earbuds is to cancel out that background white noise, this is the pair for you. The sound quality is great, not too heavy on the base. The case for the earbuds stood out from the rest as the only one that impressed me. Felt very study, and I had no worries tossing it into a gym bag or cup holder. The only case with a button latch to make sure it doesn‚Äôt open accidentally.Cons ‚Äì This was the most expensive pair of earbuds by a longshot, and there were still some things I felt could be improved. The rubber inserts had more of a ‚Äúflayed‚Äù shape rather than the ‚Äúrounded‚Äù shape that is standard. My guess is that this was by design, because the earbuds were also slightly heavier than others and may need that extra in-ear grip. The flayed shape did make them sturdier, but at the cost of them being uncomfortable in an active situation. They were also the largest earbuds, and stuck out from the side of my head further than I would have liked.My favorite? The beats fit pro! While I wouldn‚Äôt recommend this pair for everyone, it was perfect for my routine. My music taste benefits from the boosted base, and the wingtip shape was perfect for any workouts. The feature that really convinced me was the physical buttons, something that I didn‚Äôt realize how desperately I needed.

title: 4.0 out of 5 stars Not the most comfortable
author: Theo
content: The **Beats Fit Pro** is a versatile pair of true wireless earbuds that caters to both Android and iPhone users. Let's dive into the details:1. **Audio Quality (5/5):** The standout feature of the **Fit Pro** is its impressive sound quality. The bass is punchy, mids are clear, and highs are well-defined. Whether you're at the gym or in the office, the audio experience is top-notch.2. **Comfort and Fit (4/5):** The earbuds come with an intuitive ear tip fit test, ensuring a snug fit. However, some users may find the wing tips a bit uncomfortable during extended wear. If you're okay with shorter sessions, the comfort level is decent.3. **Noise Cancellation (4/5):** The active noise cancellation (ANC) works effectively, blocking out ambient noise. It's not on par with premium ANC headphones, but it gets the job done.4. **Design and Build (4/5):** The Fit Pro's rounded housings and tapered wing tips give them a unique look. The case is compact and easy to carry. However, the chunky earpieces might not appeal to everyone.5. **Price (3/5):** Here's where the Fit Pro falls short. At $199.99 USD, they're on the pricey side. If they were a tad more affordable, they'd easily earn that fifth star.In summary, the **Beats Fit Pro** delivers excellent audio quality and comfort, but the price tag holds it back from perfection. If you're an iPhone user seeking workout earbuds, these are worth considering.

title: 5.0 out of 5 stars Finally, Something By Beats I Can Endorse
author: Jeff Gomske
content: I work in radio. I've done it for 30+ years and one of the curses/blessings of working with audio is I have grown to understand intimately what really good audio sounds like. I have used countless number of headphones and earbuds (and there ùôÑùôé a difference between the two) and there are a few names which stand above the rest, and I'm not going to get into a debate because so-called, 'Audiophiles' will claim they know better (Which begs the question, how does one actually ùôóùôöùôòùô§ùô¢ùôö an Audiophile in the first place? Is there a course you can take, or does one simply give themselves that title? But I digress...) when Beats first hit the scene, they were unquestionably an astonishing waste of money. Their audio quality was maybe a shade above average at best. But, that didn't stop millions of people from buying them at outrageous prices. Well, the uncontested King of over-priced products (apple) got wind of this and did a takeover of their products and an interesting thing happened: their quality got BETTER.Did they become as good as most "professional" headphones out there...? Probably not. However, their earbuds did become notably better. I feel it necessary to point out that while Beats headphones were nowhere as good as many claimed, their earbuds from the beginning seemed to be pretty good from the get-go. Their unique "hook" style which wrapped around your ear for a secure fit (you either love this style or not - but you cannot argue that they did not fit and stay in place better than almost any other brand out there). Some of their other wired earbuds were still decent as well, if not priced at the upper end of what most people were willing to pay, but at least the earbuds could be counted on to give you an above average experience.Apple buys them out and reorganizes the entire company. Suddenly they are no longer all over the place like they used to be. Famous people were no longer wearing them everywhere you looked. Then apple releases their Beats branded earbuds, the Powerbeats Pro. Love them or hate them, they made an impact.They were also equipped with apple tech like their H1 chip which made them instantly compatible with iPhones (a pretty smart move, actually) and the audio was excellent, especially for working out. Then they release the Beats Fit Pro.A radically different design. But - a welcome one, especially for someone who loved the Powerbeats great audio quality, but not the hook design. Again, it's hard to please everyone when it comes to something that fits inside your ears that have so many different possible sizes and an almost infinite number of differences from one person to the next...like the apple airpods, one size fit ùô¢ùô§ùô®ùô©...and if you were one of the people they did not fit, well you were kind of SOL. At least with the Fit Pro they opened up better fitting to a much larger segment than the airpods and with the included wing-tip design, they immediately caught the eye of many athletes who need earbuds which stay put while sometimes being fairly aggressive in their workouts. If you were not a fan of the Powerbeats hook style, the Fit Pro's must have looked like a gift from On High.FIrst off, they really DO sound great. Good bass without going too deep. Music NEEDS good bass, but if it thumps too hard, it will ruin audio in more ways than I can describe here. Mids and Highs were also both pretty crisp and not overly isolated. The blend just works. Whoever tuned the Fit Pro should be commended for doing such a great job.ANC was...disappointing. To be fair, to get great ANC into such a tiny device really IS a challenge and oftentimes going all-in on this feature usually means you sacrifice audio quality. In this case, Beats chose to put more into the audio than into the ANC. I had a difficult time even recognizing that it was even turned on at all. Maybe my pair simply isn't doing it's job. However, the OnePlus buds Z2 has ANC that is actually pretty good and still has really impressive audio as well, so I'm not exactly sure why the Fit Pro's is so difficult to even tell if ANC is on or off, but I can only review what I have and that seems to be the case with my particular pair.The wing-tip design really works well - for me at least. They provide a pretty good fit and they stay put incredibly well. My biggest problem with earbuds is exactly that. Either they'll fit well, or almost not at all. It doesn't seem to fall anywhere in between. My OnePlus buds Z2 sound great, but I constantly find myself adjusting them in my ears - which honestly is annoying. The Fit Pro's (at least in my case) I set them in, twist to secure the wing-tip and they just stay put. This is going to be subjective since everyone is slightly different, so keep in mind my experience with how they fit in my ear may not mirror your own.You can do a little customizing with the app. I do have an iPhone but I primarily use an android, so I downloaded the app and you can to a bit of customizing, however, not as much as I would have liked to have seen given what these earbuds are capable of. I believe the iPhone integration has quite a bit more options than the android counterpart. This seems to be more the norm these days as apple and Samsung work hard to reward you for buying products that are more in line with their products than the competition. I wish they'd both put an end to this childish bickering and open up all their products that can be used on other platforms to include all the options that they would have if you paired it with an iPhone or a Samsung. Either you want your customers to get the best bang for their buck or not.I like the physical buttons the Fit Pro uses. You'll know by touch that you've pressed it instead of simply the "touch" controls which in my experience can be hit or miss. When they work great, it's awesome. But do they all work perfectly every time? Of course not. With buttons, they seem to work pretty much 100% of the time and that's something I appreciate.No wireless charging. At this point, especially for the cost, that really is something they should have included. Is it a deal breaker? For some it very well could be. It wasn't for me, but I love wireless charging and think every pair of wireless earbuds over $100 really ought to include it. I know earbuds that cost under $40 that do, so to not include it here seems to be almost an insult. They use USB-C charging which IS convenient however. Beats claims they have fast charging however, in fact they call it "Fast Fuel" where just 5 minutes of charging will net you an hour of listening...I haven't been able to check this, but I CAN state that they do seem to charge pretty quick, so that may negate some of the disappointment of not having wireless ability, but necessarily so.The case is pretty nice, too. It is quite a bit smaller than the case for the Powerbeats, but still larger than what you get with the airpods. I honestly didn't mind the size at all, so this one is also going to be pretty subjective.For the most part, these are the first apple made earbuds that I can recommend even if you own an android device. The audio is stellar and they seem to hold a charge for about an average length of time for earbuds of this size. I rarely listen for more than about an hour, maybe 2 at the most, so I'm not the guy to look for with advice on listening at length (unless it's for headphones, then I can make a LOT of recommendations). Honestly, I'm happy with mine. Are they perfect? No. But are they worth it? I sure think so.***UPDATE***I purchased some memory foam eartips...not sure that this was a wise decision. Not because they don't work or fit well, but because they are slightly larger, it means fitting them back into the charging case either they won't charge or they'll be problematic to fit properly. Now, in all fairness, this wasn't an issue with the smallest foam eartips, but the medium and larger ones did not like to fit back into the case. They also did not really make any noticeable difference is audio quality, so I switched back to the original tips they came with. Lesson learned.
timestamp: Reviewed in the United States March 22, 2023
product_attributes: Color: Volt YellowStyle: Fit ProSet: Without AppleCare+

title: 4.0 out of 5 stars Wonderful sound quality, great features, but missing one important feature
author: J. Sierra
content: I'll start by stating that I appreciate and recognize great quality audio, and certainly prefer the highest quality audio that I can reasonably get when I'm listening to headphones and/or earbuds. That being said, the important word here is "reasonably", and I don't have tremendous expectations from earbuds that are also intended for working out, etc. it's just not reasonable to expect to compare them to over-ear headphones, in terms of quality or features. Noise cancellation, bass response, highs, mids.... Over-ear are always going to edge out earbuds. There's just more space to make it all work.Ok that's out of the way. I didn't have huge expectations and I wasn't even convinced that the buds would be worth the $150 (they were on sale when I bought them.) I'm not convinced *any* ear bud is worth more than $100, and I've tried some very "high-end" units.So I pulled the trigger with some hesitation, received them, charged them up, paired em to my phone after downloading the proprietary Beats app (didn't like that, but there's good news), popped em in (after trying the different sized ends) and went on a run (because I feel like that constant bouncing is the likeliest to cause them to fall out.)I was.... Extremely surprised. Surprised and a little impressed. Sound quality is actually really, really good... Far better than I would've expected from a Beats product, more akin to the high quality Sony and Technics units. There are two "modes", sound-cancelling and transparency mode (transparency mode allows for awareness of what's going on around you by almost enhancing ambient noise.) Noise cancellation is surprisingly good, though yes, okay, not the absolute best I've heard but it's in the top 3 for ear buds, no question. It's effective, even if it eats battery up like crazy. I appreciate transparency mode though - especially while running or biking. It's not disturbing to have the ambient noise available and there's a safety component there that can't be overstated. And it works really well.Pairing them up was a little... Interesting. They're clearly designed by and for Apple people, so if you're rocking that Apple tech the process is probably mostly automated (that's as advertised) but with Android you theoretically have you use a Beats app. At first that aggravated me (I really hate proprietary apps) but then the pairing failed and I discovered that I could indeed pair via Bluetooth, it's super fast and easy, and the Beats app just gives me a handy place to activate some features/controls. I can't speak to the Apple experience though.Charging is where I was actually disappointed enough to take a star off the product. The case is ok, has cool little magnets to keep the buds in place, but it only works as a charging station when plugged in. No wireless charging. That's a huge miss for Beats. Huge. There are a ton of comparable products at that price profile and all of them offer wireless charging. It's maybe not a deal breaker and they do have ok battery life but it's... Extremely disappointing. Battery life is going to depend a lot on whether you use noise cancellation or not. Kind of a big fluctuation there, ymmv, maybe not the best but definitely far from the worst. They certainly last well beyond exercise sessions, and are capable of giving most of your day music. Again though, lack of wireless charging is blatantly, conspicuously missing. And it's annoying because if it had wireless charging the battery life would almost become inconsequential. Fortunately, thanks to Amazon, there are actually aftermarket cases that do have wireless charging, giving you approximately three days worth of charge. It's an extra thirty bucks so it's something you'll want to keep in mind/consider as part of ownership. Don't get me wrong, it's not a deal breaker - there's plenty of battery life - but it's one of those things that premium buds should have. Period. And these are supposed to be premium buds.The fit is exceptionally comfortable. There are several tips that help with sealing but also support the stability in the ear while doing exercise. After a run/jog session they stayed in without any issues. Even with plenty of sweat, they were good to go. The extra little fin protrusion also contributed effectively to it staying in and in place. I would have been more surprised at this but I've been using ear bud hearing protection recently and they're so light and well fitting that I know what good buds are capable of in this particular domain.The features are actually pretty neat, but mostly expected, like swapping automatically from buds to phone and back again, going single-bud with nary a hiccup, and plenty more. They're pretty slick in functionality. The buttons are also tactile, providing a neat click; seems like a little thing but from an interface perspective it's a surprisingly big deal, and it works really well.So, are they good? I think that they're overpriced but I think all ear buds these days are so, grain of salt. I think they're very very good buds, they exceeded my admittedly mid expectations, they function flawlessly and most importantly: they deliver great sound. Would I buy them for two bills? Eh.... Knowing what I know now about them and how good they are, that goes from a hard no to a soft maybe. At $150ish I think they're a decent value. Are they better than over ear options? Not in terms of sheer quality no, but: they're a million times better for exercise and working out. Unless you like being one of those douchey gym rats with the Beats over-ear. Then I can't help you.For the rest of us, these are a very fine choice. Sony and Technics have offerings that actually do have intensely high quality audio, but these come close enough in terms of audio and they're good for a sweaty, bouncy, jouncy session of your favorite exercise, whatever that might be.As always, ymmv. But hey, with Amazon if you don't like em, you can just return them. Hopefully my review helped a little.Merry Christmas!

title: 5.0 out of 5 stars My New Daily Driver
author: Dylan Geuss
content: I really like these a lot, I got them through Amazon Resale for a much cheaper price, however they were still basically brand new, so I feel like I lucked out on these puppies! For the longest time I've struggled with finding earbuds that are able to stay in my ear without the fear of feeling them slowly slipping out overtime, thanks to the amazing wingtips! Every other earbuds I have bought and used over the years did not have wingtips, and as a result, due to the shape of my ears, they would eventually fall out after doing so much as just walking with them in.I'm not audiophile, but these sound great, very comparable to my Pixel Buds Pro in terms of quality, albeit with less options for tuning the sound to your tastes, but that's not something I concern myself too much with anyway, since for me personally, I don't need many options other than just wanting them to work and sound good out of the box. There's plenty of bass, but it's not so much that it overwhelms everything else about the sound, when listening to music anyway.These were able to pair to my phone pretty easily once I downloaded the Beats app from the Play Store, and setup is about as simple as it gets! Open the case, tap the sync button, and boom, you're off to the races! Bluetooth is very stable from the time I've used them so far, no random disconnects or audio garbling as far as I can tell.These come with their own USB-C cable for charging, and it's just like any other earbuds that charge the same way, and although the lack of wireless charging is apparent, it was never something I used much anyway, so for me, I'm fine with plugging these in when the juice gets low. In terms of how far these reach while in use, they seem to have a range of about 30 feet or so, I was able to walk around my apartment while using them and they had no issues staying connected.Overall, these are a great pair, definitely consider picking them up for yourself if you've had issues with more typical earbuds staying secure in your ears. I got a much better deal on these than the standard price, but even still, I think these are worth every dollar.

Us audiophiles are hard to please and picky....so don't listen to our complaints as closely.Leave those for the audiophiles to read about.Connectivity --- Excellent. 5 stars.With that said ...If you need something to work out in, live in a hot environment and are cleaning your yard.These are the ones for you. Not the Studio Buds .. And my ears are pretty versatile.Which is why during this past July 15th and 16th 2024 Amazon Days, I just purchased the Beats Fit Pro set.The sound on the Fits... Not gonna lie, huge difference in quality.Wasn't expecting it to be that different.But, alas, it is.Now with that said, these are not as affordable as the Studio Buds as I said previously..The fits, not on sale and on sale, not for a budget audio seeker, unless needing them to stay in, is a must. title: 4.0 out of 5 stars Good for Apple ecosystem - not fully convinced at price point
author: decadeindc
content: UPDATE 17 Feb 2024: Had to buy another pair after 13 months. The takeaway is: clean your earbuds thoroughly every 3-4 weeks with a earbud cleaning tool. There is a small screen on the little earbud sound exit point that‚Äôs visible when the ear tip is removed. That screen came entirely off on one earbud and the other earbud was partially blocked from impacted ear wax that had hardened so much that it fused to the screen (which is fragile and not attached to the housing with much glue). I cleaned the silicone tips regularly, but never cleaned those small openings and screens, much to my peril. (And yes, I clean my ears daily.) The earbuds still technically work ok, but without those screens in place, it‚Äôs only a matter of time before additional ear wax begins to change the sound and eventually corrode or block the drivers.Otherwise, my year-plus of experience with these earbuds was great. I used them for a minimum of an hour every day, and often much longer. They fit comfortably, produce great sound, hold good battery life, easily connect to all my Apple devices. I misjudged the battery life in my original review. Transparency mode is fine and noise canceling is good, although I‚Äôm not sure the trade off with battery life from ‚Äúnormal‚Äù mode is always worth it. The trade off of wired USB-C charging and no wireless charging is something I can live with. Don‚Äôt think any earbud is comfortable enough to wear all day on conference calls, but certainly around four hours is fine. I‚Äôve experienced more than a few instances where the sound stops playing via my iPhone randomly and it looks like the Bluetooth connection has severed. I can‚Äôt just press on the left earbud to start playing again, I have to physically press play on my iPhone app and magically the earbuds start working again. Hard to tell what the problem is, but it happens once a week or so. Still think the price/value ratio is about as good as any other wireless earbud, especially in the Apple ecosystem, including AirPods.Original review ‚Ä¶ Pros: comfy for in-ear buds, especially for physical activity, works really nicely with Apple‚Äôs ecosystem including spatial audio, noise cancellation is very good as is transparency mode, sound quality is decent, can use one bud at a time if desired, USB-C charging. Cons: no multipoint connectivity, no wireless charging, water resistance rating lower than many other earbuds, battery life is barely adequate (both buds and charging case), outgoing audio voice quality is also just adequate.These are good earbuds, no question. But there are some maddening features skipped here that appear on much less expensive Bluetooth products. I still don‚Äôt understand why Apple‚Äôs Bluetooth audio products don‚Äôt include multipoint connectivity, even within their own ecosystem. My ancient Plantronics ear piece and my Bose headphones have had multipoint for years, and lack of it is really annoying when using the Beats for work purposes. Lack of wireless charging is less a concern for me, but is annoying at this price point if you‚Äôve invested in the technology. The outgoing voice quality is probably fine for the form factor of the Beats, but it does sound like a telephone call when using Teams or Zoom rather than high quality audio. Biggest bug for me is these won‚Äôt make it through a full eight hour day of calls without a recharge, and the case only holds enough charge for 35 hours of use. I have a pair of Anker Life Dot 2s that are 5.5x less expensive with a 100 hour case that isn‚Äôt really any bigger. I realize many other buds won‚Äôt hit that eight hour mark either, so maybe it‚Äôs a complaint about the form factor.The sound quality is fine considering the Bluetooth codec used by Apple (either source or headphone) isn‚Äôt high def or even CD quality, despite what Apple might want you to think with the inclusion of spatial audio capability on the Beats. The drivers on the Beats are certainly acceptable for most users and given the mission and price point of the Beats, it‚Äôs about as good as anybody should expect. There‚Äôs room for improvement, but not much more without moving up in price or a change in codec use by Apple.One thing I did expect was a better water resistance rating. IPX4 is a little weak considering iPhones are at IP67.What I do really like is the noise cancellation (and transparency mode done well) of the Beats. Really works well. The earbuds are very comfortable to wear and get a good seal. The ear wings hold the earbuds in the ear without turning uncomfortable. Love the Apple ecosystem integration - these connect very easily with simple adjustments to iPhone and MacBook Pro alike.If you like the idea of AirPods Pro that fit better and stay in your ear more securely, you‚Äôll probably like these. Again, for the price, these seem to hit most marks for what they are, which is a sort of Jack-of-all-trades Bluetooth earbud. Be sure to shop around if you value one specific element over another, like audio quality or battery life.

title: 5.0 out of 5 stars Great Earbuds

content: Great earbuds. Only thing is I had to get them serviced, by Apple, not even a month in because of some defection that caused them to randomly screech then one went out. If you're in the market for some good earbuds for everything, including working out, these are for you, if you don't mind spending a little bit more.The charging is case is a tad bulky bit it's cool at the same time.
