title: 4.0 out of 5 stars Works good on calls, at least for me
author: Wade Burchette
content: I bought these only because I needed something that let me talk while working, but still keep my hands free. I have a need to work on equipment while talking to various companies tech support lines. While a speakerphone does allow me to hear them, it does not help them to hear me. I did not buy this for music, because my cheap wired headphones with a USB-C connector deliver better music quality due to those pesky laws of physics. (It should be illegal for phones to remove the 3.5mm headphone jack.) Despite how they look, for me they work just fine for calls. However, I can see their design would also cause them not to work for some people. Be prepared to return them if that is the case.Setting up the earpiece was relatively straightforward. Since I already have a Samsung phone, I decided on these. The Galaxy wearable app opened, and the process started. It included 3 difference sized earpieces, and the app said each one was not a good fit. So I stuck with the medium sized piece.By default noise cancellation was on. But this quickly gave me a terrible headache. 5 minutes with these in and noise cancellation going was enough to give me a headache for the rest of the day. I turned off noise cancellation the next day and I didn't get a headache. I think I got motion sickness due to the noise cancellation.I haven't tested the battery life. These headphones are for work, not music. I only did a limited test in music quality, again because my only concern is telephone conversations. For that, they work fine for me.Update: I finally tested the music for this. The quality was good enough, but clearly inferior to a cheap set of wired headphones. Also, the delay in bluetooth is evident in videos if you look close enough. The lack of physical buttons is a serious issue. While working outside, a gnat got in my ear and to get it out, I had to touch an earpiece which paused the music. I found myself frequently accidentally touching them; very aggravating. Although it was nice to be able to work outside a few feet away from my phone. Kept my phone from getting damaged. None of the advantages outweigh the advantages of a proper headphone jack, but it is a nice ALTERNATIVE in certain situations.Also, irreplaceable batteries should be very very illegal, even for tiny headphones like this.
timestamp: Reviewed in the United States July 1, 2023

title: 4.0 out of 5 stars Great sound. Software is not quite at "pro" level.
author: Jason
content: Let's get the obvious out of the way. These are fantastic sounding. End of story. If you are looking for sound quality out of a wireless set of earbuds, you can almost just stop here and be fine.My smaller issue is the fit. They fit pretty well, but aren't staying in for longer periods of time. I feel like I'm always re-adjusting them. I will have to see if comply foam tips will fit as those will probably help resolve that issue.My bigger issue is actually the software. God forbit any one company get things right. I've had Sennheiser Momentums that sounded really good, but over time died so I moved on to the venerable Sony XM3's. They were really nice, but you couldn't adjust the volume like you could with the Sennheisers. Ok fine, their software allowed for a lot of customization though. I won't ever go back to Sony's though as the battery life on those is absolutely terrible. Not when they're new. But after only about a year the XM3's wouldn't hold a charge. I thought moving to the XM4's would help, but alas, after a year they wouldn't hold a charge either. Not sure what Sony is doing battery wise, but they need to do something else.So I moved on from the Sony's to these. Right away, I liked the sound of these so much more. But the software, while nice, is not very friendly when it comes to customizing them. You can't set anything to be whatever you want. You can't set the left and right to do individual things. My left is set to where if I hold it the earbuds go from ANC to Ambient sound and vice versa. The right side is set to go between Normal and ANC. But you can't set one side to go through the three settings (like you can on Sony). Why? This seems nonsensical. Also, with the Sony's I could have them connected to two devices at once and it would just play whichever device was being used. Not these.While I highly recommend them for sound quality, the software, while looking good, is actually weird and a little clunky. To me, it's not quite PRO level. Maybe some future updates will get it there though.

title: 4.0 out of 5 stars App Requires 100pct Phone Access
author: Speedbyrd
content: First and most important, these are just Bluetooth-connected. YOU DO NOT HAVE TO DOWNLOAD THE APP.I was happy to learn you can connect these buds like any Bluetooth speaker or headphones. They fit well, they have a great sound. I assume the app would have explained those functions.If Samsung reads this, change the app! I don't want to make a phone call or send a text message with earbuds. I bought them to just listen to music. The app should not require all that permission. The first song I played was, "I did it my way."
timestamp: Reviewed in the United States December 31, 2023

title: 5.0 out of 5 stars A journey from Galaxy Buds+ to Galaxy Buds 2 to Galaxy Buds 2 Pro
author: Jenna Rhine
content: So here is an initial Day 1 review.I started with the Galaxy Buds+ and was "generally" happy. The sound quality was excellent, the volume decent, the phone calls were acceptable and the fit was comfortable and stayed in place (for about 30 minutes) My biggest problem was the "wings." They helped the buds stay in place but due to the design, they tended to rotate since they were only being aligned by a tiny plastic nub. And once the wings rotated the fit was horrible.So I eventually upgraded to the Galaxy Buds 2. These also sounded very good, better in fact than the Galaxy Buds+. The calls and audio volume were similar, so perfectly functional. But now I had noise cancelling and a brand new form factor! The noise cancelling worked great for my needs. I'm not flying all over the country, but they nicely limited the white noise of public spaces. Unfortunately the fit was even worse. The Galaxy Buds 2 were slightly oblong in comparison to the Buds+, which I believed would be the answer to the "wandering wings" and finally give me the stable fit I'd been looking for. Alas, this was not the case. The only way the buds would stay in my ear is from a friction fit of the cushions in my ear canal. Not comfortable! And if I spoke or chewed food, it was only a matter of seconds before they had worked themselves loose. In every way except fit, the Galaxy Buds 2 were a definite upgrade.Now we arrive at the Galaxy Buds 2 Pro. I have had them for about 5 hours and here are my initial impressions:- Getting them in the right orientation took me some time (probably because I'd been historically wearing ear buds goofy just to try to get them to stay in my ear.)- Once I had the ear buds in correctly, the fit was surprisingly comfortable and "light" feeling. At first I questioned whether they were positioned properly (the ambient noise being on also added to the idea.) When I turned off the ambient noise I realized how well the buds were fitting.- Chewing and speaking did not disrupt the fit at all!- The ANC worked as expected.- The sound was EXCELLENT in comparison to the previous Buds+ and Buds 2. I found the Buds 2 Pro to be louder, crisper and punchier than the previous earbuds.That's it for now. I'm cautiously optimistic about my purchase and I will follow up in a few weeks with more review. Moving forward I'll be focusing on how easy/hard it will be to quickly position the buds in and how much I end up "messing with them" while wearing them.

title: 3.0 out of 5 stars Jabra Elite 7 Pro vs 75t and Galaxy Buds+
author: Alexander
content: I recently bought Jabra 7 Elite Pros in addition to Jabra 75t's and Galaxy Buds+ that I already own, so I'll compare them in this review against each other.Comfort-wise, I did find Jabra 7 to be more comfortable than 75t and much more comfortable than Galaxy Buds+ (small ears). J7 is the clear winner in comfort department for me.Case. At first I liked it. But only after some use I realized how inconvenient it is to open with one hand, especially when your skin gets a little bit dry and there's absolutely not enough grip on the lid and no notch to hold on to. Many people also report frequently dropping the case when trying to open it with one hand. This is actually a problem that is exclusive to Elite 7 because neither 75t nor Galaxy Buds+ have it.Sound-wise I'm not an expert, but I like the way they sound. But then again, I also like the way 75t's sound as well as Galaxy Buds+.Simultaneous connection to two devices: I bet galaxy buds, and Sony users don't even realize how great it is to connect to your PC and phone at the same time. Both Jabra 7 and 75t's can be connected to two devices (although only one is allowed to play sound at any given time) and that's a fundamentally important feature that most other wireless headphones lack.Single earpiece use: Jabra 7 has better support of using earpieces individually compared to 75t's: you can listen to either the left one or the right one, when 75t's allows you to use only the right one individually. Galaxy buds can work with either too. So 75t's lose their point here.My right earbud initially had some sort of a clicking sound when I chewed, but that seems to have fixed itself after a couple days.One of the most important aspects for me is the treadmill test: can any of them withstand daily intense running? Galaxy buds keep falling out of my ears and pinch the inner part of my ear with their wing tips. Also annoyingly whenever I try to fix them in place, their touch controls keep triggering which is infinitely frustrating. 75t's withstood more than a year of treadmill abuse from me, they performed well enough, but ultimately sweat did kill them: their sound started dipping when pressure inside the ear changed and later on sound almost disappeared. Jabra 7 Elite Pro seem to fit me the best: they sit very tight and they are comfortable while running. I'm yet to find out how long they will last.Buttons/controls. 75t's have very good physical buttons that you never activate by accident and they're light enough to respond without pushing the thing into your brain. Galaxy buds have touch controls which in my opinion is a huge design flaw because it keeps triggering whenever you want to fix the earpiece's position in your ear. Jabra 7's buttons are much more rigid and require more force to be pushed. It's not too bad, but I think I prefer 75t's controls that are softer.Stability. I never had any software/firmware problems with 75t's or galaxy buds, but J7's greeted me with a stalled green light on the case (not supposed to happen) and a whole bunch of jumping through the hoops to update them (it refused to go according to plan). While I managed to pull it through, I bet some people would have just sent them back already in frustration.So, the verdict. Is it worth upgrading from 75t's? Unless they're broken, probably not. Is it worth upgrading over Galaxy Buds+? I'd say, yes, because connecting to two devices at the same time becomes an essential feature once you start using it. Heck, I'd upgrade just because of how much more comfortable they are.
timestamp: Reviewed in the United States August 23, 2022
product_name: Jabra Elite 7 Pro - True Wireless Earbuds

title: 4.0 out of 5 stars Good, but not great. Some design issues
author: Alex M
content: I bought these earbuds after returning a pair of Bose Sport Earbuds due to terrible microphone quality. I saw that these had better reviews for phone calls, and I was willing to try a different brand.What I liked:-BUTTONS. I love the physical buttons, which are much easier to use than touch controls. Especially when my hands are busy or wet (like washing dishes), its easy to just rock my head to the side and press the buttons to pause.-The sound quality was good. I'm not an audiophile by any means, but I'm happy.-The case has wireless charging, which was a nice addition.-The earbuds have a good fit that isn't too uncomfortable after a while of listening.-The app is of higher quality than the Bose and Sony one is, at least it seemed intuitive to me.What was 'meh':-I bought these earbuds for the supposed better call quality, but the microphone sounds mediocre on the other end. It doesn't fare well at all in strong winds either. It's still better than the Bose, but I was a little disappointed by the microphone performance, considering the reviews. I mainly just use cheap wired earbuds with a microphone for better call quality.-The ANC that was added from a software update doesn't do anything. I've tested it on a noisy bus, and a loud gym, and I can't hear any difference between the 'off' and the 'ANC' modes. I just keep it in 'off' mode all the time, and I haven't seen any appreciable battery drain.-There's a 'sidetone' feature enabled by default that's meant to help you hear yourself when you're in a call, but it is just an annoying echo. You can turn it off in the app.What I didn't like:-The case is made of slippery plastic that's hard to open one handed. Even with two hands, you have to press in the top of the case to open it. Because of the symmetrical design of the case, its also hard to tell what is the top, bottom, or front of the case without directly looking at it. It makes the case annoying to hold and work with, and I've already dropped it twice, scattering the earbuds on the floor.-The software can be buggy. When I'm watching YouTube videos, occasionally, I'll resume the video after pausing, only to hear no sound. The volume is on, and no sound from any app plays. The only way to fix this is to put the earbuds back in the case then take them out.In short, these earbuds are a good product, but with some flaws that could be fixed in the next iteration. I'm happy enough that I got these at a slight discount by timing the order, but I still feel I overpaid for the quality I got. I wouldn't buy these at 'full price'. Still happier than if I kept the Bose though.

title: 4.0 out of 5 stars My Favorite Ear Buds
author: Alex Ruiz
content: Update: after a few weeks of use, the microphone appears to not be working as well as when I first purchased. Seems to be a common issue with no real fix from what I‚Äôve read. People have trouble hearing me speak, sounding like I am far away, which is disappointing to say the least, so I‚Äôm knocking off 1 star, as they are still great for music.I had a pair of Elite 75t ear buds in 2020 that I absolutely loved. I originally used with them with a Samsung phone and I (begrudgingly) switched to Apple in 2021 with no issues. I hadn‚Äôt tried any other ear buds at that point and didn‚Äôt feel the need to. The fit, sound and call quality were perfect for my needs. As is usually the case with my luck, the Summer of 2022 I left my 75t‚Äôs soaking in my jeans for a few hours, which pretty much ruined them. Having switched to using an iPhone, I allowed myself to be convinced to get AirPods. As this is a Jabra review, I won‚Äôt go into details about the AirPods other than I was not impressed with everything about them, especially the fit and should have returned them immediately.Fast forward to Summer 2023, with my AirPods needing to be replaced because the right ear bud constantly buzzes, I opted to switch back to Jabra with the Elite 7 Pro‚Äôs and I have to say I‚Äôm happy I made the switch back. Fit was a big complaint with the AirPods, and the Jabra‚Äôs fit like a glove, never needing to be adjusted or feel like they are falling out even during intense exercise. Sound and call quality again is perfect for my needs. I work out a lot and work construction and I use my ear buds for phone calls quite frequently, so the water and dust proof ratings as well as the better mic are what convinced me to go with the 7 Pros this time. I completely forgot how good the battery life was as well compared to AirPods.The thing I like the most is definitely the fit, so if fit has ever been an issue with ear buds, I recommend giving the Elite 7 Pro‚Äôs, or Jabra ear buds in general, a try. A very good value for the price.

title: 3.0 out of 5 stars Dissapointed
author: curtasian
content: I was trying to replace a Plantronics ELITE16 mono headset. Overall these would have been good if it weren't for a couple glaring problems.The Pros:*They fit very well, once you get used to them. I don't think that was due to any issues with the earbuds, your ears simply take time to adjust to having something in them that snugly for very long. I was able to go several hours and almost forget they were in. They never came loose.*The Active noice cancelling and audio sound was great. I mowed a lawn on the second day I owned them. I turned on the noise cancelling. This made the mower and string trimmer a quiet as they were when I used only earmuffs. A song started playing that I wasn't familiar with, it started out with a roller coaster and then people cheering and having fun. Since I didn't know the song, and because the audio was great I suddenly heard a whooshing sound and lots of people making noise . . . I thought something was happening and stopped the mower to look and find what all the commotion was about, only to realize it was the music. I looked around, thankfully no one saw me.*Single bud usage. I really like being able to use one earbud at a time. I was also worried if I lost one I wouldn't be able to use them at all, but either bud will work without the other.The cons:*I bought them because they were supposed to be good in noisy environments, but even at my desk I had to talk very loudly before people could hear me. This happened both on phone calls and in online meetings.*The hearthrough feature was not good. First I think they tuned the hearthrough so that the really important sounds get through. For instance, I could hear people who were near me pretty well, and I could hear most car sounds (like horns, sirens, obnoxiously loud music, etc.) as I drove. That's good, but all of the ambiance was lost. When I put them in, it sounded like I was listening through paper towel tubes. I could faintly hear the fan near me, it sounded like hiss instead of a fan. I could not hear almost anything that was more than a few feet from me unless it was really loud or one of the previously mentioned sounds. I could usually hear people who were speaking loudly, but if someone was outside my office I could only hear muffled sounds. I assume they tuned the Hearthrough for a combination of safety and battery life.The in between:*The battery life wasn't great, but I figured it wouldn't be as good as what I was replacing since they are smaller and do more. They probably had the rated runtime but with the hearthrough going the whole time I only got about 5 hours out of them. I ran them one earbud at a time unless I needed both for music, which was about 20 minutes each day.The Plantronics cost me about $50 3 years ago. I just wanted better sound and the ANC - and I got it, but it was at the cost of: battery life, call clarity, and ability to hear around me. I considered the inability to communicate effectively on calls a defect, and I sent them back.

timestamp: Reviewed in the United States December 4, 2022
product_name: Jabra Elite 7 Pro - True Wireless Earbuds

title: 5.0 out of 5 stars Lived up to expectations
author: Oliver
content: Upgraded to these from 65t's, which were my first pair of wireless headphones. Of all the great options out there I chose these because I wanted to stay in the Jabra ecosystem and had a good experience with my 65t's. Was also looking for earbuds that could work independently of each other, which was not a feature of the 65t's but is with these, which I think is a necessity to avoid what happened to my 65t's where you end up with a dead battery in one earbud and a totally usable one in the other. tl;dr: they were a significant upgrade that I have very few complaints with, and if you're happy with other Jabra products or just can't decide I think it's hard to go wrong with these.Sound quality is a noticeable upgrade from the 65t's, punchy base and an excellent soundstage. Started right away with the "hearing test" that Jabra provides in their app so I can't speak to the sound quality without doing that but I've seen in other reviews that it can make a significant difference. Haven't used the ANC much but when I do it does the job, haven't tried other options so I don't really know what I'm missing out on but it cuts consistent ambient noise (i.e., road noise, presumably plane noises as well) pretty well. HearThrough is also much better than with the 65t's, but I find I have to crank it up to the highest setting to make a conversation intelligible, but the music still retains the same punchy quality in this mode which surprised me.Connectivity and range are on par with the 65t's, I've left my phone on the other side of an Olympic size pool while running laps and they stay connected.Haven't used the microphone much but haven't gotten any complaints, will update if the pickup quality is severely lacking but from other reviews I've seen the microphone is decent.Battery life is also a step up from the 65t's, I've charged the case maybe two or three times since I got them delivered about a month ago which is probably about for the frequency and length of my usage.I occasionally wear them in the gym and have noticed what other reviewers have referred to as the sensation that the buds are about to fall out; I've yet to have one fall out and have found that pressing them in a little deeper tends to fix the issue, but if you're a runner or other high-movement athlete perhaps these aren't the buds for you.
timestamp: Reviewed in the United States July 17, 2023
product_name: Jabra Elite 7 Pro - True Wireless Earbuds

title: 4.0 out of 5 stars So far so good. Make sure to use the app.
author: tylerite
content: I think most issues reported are due to users not using the app or improperly settings the ear buds up in the app. I've only had them a week but so far I have been very impressed. I use them daily for media and conference calls. I use them with a Pixel phone.Pro- The ANC is stellar. On a plane I had no idea there were screaming kids until I took one bud out.- The battery life is some sort of magic. It's longer than any Bluetooth audio device I've owned.- integrated Alexa was a huge selling point for me and works well.- they look great. Way better than white straws hanging from your ears.- personally I love that the buttons are actually buttons and not touchCons- the hear through works ok, it's not good enough to hold a full conversation with but it will keep you aware.*- there's a weird setting for hear through on calls that let's you hear your own voice. It doesn't work great, turn it off.*- I have had issues with them not turning off when I put them back in the case and occasionally the left bud not connecting properly. Rare issues.- it seems they don't play well with laptops for video conferencing... Not sure what that's about, it's not an issue for me as I typically use both phone and laptop anyway.*These may require further app tweakingAll in all 4 stars. Would be 5 if the call quality were better and hear through were improved. Maybe they'll get there as I learn to use them better.
timestamp: Reviewed in the United States September 4, 2023
product_name: Jabra Elite 7 Pro - True Wireless Earbuds

title: 4.0 out of 5 stars Super Comfy Fit = Good Value
author: Marcelo Weiss
content: I am an earphone addict and love to try out different brands and different styles. Over the years, Jabra has delivered a consistent value for the money and the Elite 7 Pro did not disappoint.My favorite feature is the comfortable fit. It is a trial and error effort to find the right eargel for your shape/size of ears, but it is a must. The Jabra Sound+ app provides a good earfit test software to ensure you have a tight fit. Also, depending on your current earphone, it takes a little bit of effort to find the right insertion depth and positioning in your ear. I recommend at least one solid week of trying to feel their comfort level, do not give up on the first few days. Once they settle in, it will feel like second nature. From all the earphones I've had, this is for sure the only one I feel comfortable wearing all day long.My least favorite feature is the not-so-strong ACN (Active Noise Cancellation). Oh Jabra, if you could only make this some 30% or so better, this would be a 5-stars review. I have tried tweaking all the settings possible in the Sound+ app, but it does not get me to a level where I can tune out the sound on a medium noise level coffee shop. On a good note, you do have the ability to tune down the ANC level, which is good in certain situations where you do want more noise for safety reasons (biking for example).Battery life has not presented a problem, much for the contrary. As long as you use the charging case throughout the day, all is good for moderate to intense usage.BIG PLUS:Multipoint Connection:Yes, you can connect two devices at the same time without having to manually toggle between them. No Bluetooth setting tweaking on each device, no dropped connection, it just works! So, from laptop to phone, easy easy easy. What was annoying on other earphones, the Jabra 7 Pro makes it easy.Left & Right Button Controls:A lot of options to control through the buttons. Worth the effort to learn the one-click, two clicks, three clicks, and click-and-hold routines. And, you can program your own preferences through the app. Love it!This is a solid earphone and I recommend it for friends and family.I was rewarded for my honest recommendation of this product.
timestamp: Reviewed in the United States February 14, 2022
product_name: Jabra Elite 7 Pro - True Wireless Earbuds

title: 4.0 out of 5 stars Realistic Review
author: James Trenton Salem
content: I purchased these to upgrade my 2.5-year-old 85T's and I have mixed feelings about them. The sound, it is clear and crisp and the bass is low, bumpy, and throaty. Use of the Jabra Sound app is also a nice feature. I use my earbuds everyday for everything from listening to podcasts at work at my desk or driving around, as well as exercise mostly running on an elliptical machine. For work and low movement activities, the Elite 7s are good, but the 85T's are much better for bouncy exercise. The Elite 7s have an echo that bounces the sound in your ear, whereas the 85T's stay consistent. This is annoying when trying to focus on music and breathing during an exercise. Additionally, the 85T's are much louder than the Elite 7s, but are a bit bulkier. However, the 85T's do make use of 12mm drivers and Elite 7s only use 6mm drivers. Phone calls are also better with the 85T's, anyone I talk to with my Elite 7s asks me to speak louder, so my experience shows the 85T's are more sensitive to the user's voice. Overall, I am satisfied with my Elite 7 purchase, but I am still thinking about a new set of 85T's as the Elite 7's just don't quite get it done like the 85T's. And the egg-shaped ear gummies on the 85T's seem to come out on top between the two buds' styles of round (Elite 7) vs elliptical (85T). I hope this helps anyone weighing a decision between the two.

timestamp: Reviewed in the United States July 27, 2024
product_name: Jabra Elite 7 Pro - True Wireless Earbuds

title: 4.0 out of 5 stars Good product, but would rather buy on sale
author: Wesley Croom
content: TLDR: Good product with a lot of features, but would recommend buying it on sale, and may not fit ears well.I got this product on sale for about 120 with shipping included. I am satisfied with the product. The main downside is the buds do not fit my ear very snugly, and are prone to falling out. However, I will not blame the product for that as it is impossible for an earbud to fit all ear types, as I have small ears.The points I am most impressed with are the features included (Buttons, Jabra App, Easy connectivity, Auto Pause), and the active noise cancelling. The earbuds are very easy to use and control without having to take out your device to change settings.Other than the earbuds not fitting my ear I have 3 main gripes with the product. 1.) The charger that comes with the earbuds is way too short 2.) It is not easy to open the case for the earbuds 3.) I do not think the product is worth the full regular price of $200. As I said I got it on sale and do think I got $120 worth of earbuds, but if I spend $200 I would definitely want better sound quality and ANC. I would rather just spend $50 extra and get something like AirPods pro
timestamp: Reviewed in the United States October 18, 2023
product_name: Jabra Elite 7 Pro - True Wireless Earbuds

title: 4.0 out of 5 stars Excellent upgrade from the Jabra 85t
author: JasonB
content: Full disclosure: the Jabra 85t were my all-time favorite earbuds. My main complaint was battery life. Thankfully, the Elite 7 Pro improves battery life while still delivering excellent sound quality and noise canceling.On the DOWN SIDE...I have noticed some MAJOR connectivity issues. If you live in a world of LED lights/TVs (as many of us do), be prepared for a lot of dropped audio, disruptions, and general Bluetooth issues. I don't understand the connection between LED lights/TVs and these types of "true-wireless" buds, but they do not get along...and the Jabra Elite 7 Pro is the worst of the options I have at my house (Sony and Sennheiser Momentum).I have demoted these to "ONLY GYM" earbuds and rely on my Sennheiser for daily use...but even still, these are an excellent replacement for the 85t on battery life alone. I especially like that there is a physical button (not a touch button) on the device. This helps to prevent unintended clicks (which are a problem with my SONY and SENNHEISER). At the GYM, when my hands/biceps can be near my ears on some reps, this physical button is a major PLUS for useability.
timestamp: Reviewed in the United States November 6, 2023
product_name: Jabra Elite 7 Pro - True Wireless Earbuds

title: 3.0 out of 5 stars good earbuds for calls; bad for everything else.
author: SHM224
content: I had previously had the SONY WH1000MX4 -- needed a new earbuds while my SONY was under repair.-- GOOD --I checked rting.com and purchased it based on its sounds quality, which is almost as good as the MX4 for calls.-- BAD --Now bad, I had terrible allergic reaction the first two months. It started itching first, then my both ears started to bleed time to time. The battery charging was a bit slow and lasted about 7-8hr per charge; then noticeably reduced to 5-7hr after 6 months. No sound on the left bud after 6 month -- it charged fine and control still worked, but no sound. ANC wasn't nearly as good.This pair was eventually replaced by Jabra 8 with significant improvements in charging speed, no allergy reaction, better sound quality for music and calls.
timestamp: Reviewed in the United States May 2, 2024
product_name: Jabra Elite 7 Pro - True Wireless Earbuds

title: 4.0 out of 5 stars Great product, especially for the price
author: Robert Willey
content: These are some of the most comfortable and secure earbuds I have ever used. They sort of "screw" into the ear and sit tightly, which is great for outdoor sports. I can ski all day with them in and my ears don't hurt, and the sweat and water from snow hasn't impacted their performance one bit.They are also great for in the office. The pass through feature lets noise into the earbuds so if someone comes into the office I can hear them without them having to stand there until I look up and notice them. They also have a feature that stops playback of whatever you are listening to when you remove them. So if I am listening to a show in the background while I'm working, I pop them out and the show pauses. Pop them back in and we're off to the races. It is VERY handy.The noise cancellation is also great, some of the best I have used. I paid $200 for the headset I use on my PC and these earbuds match the quality 100%.My only complaints are minor. Whatever tracks whether you have your earbuds in or not is a little sensitive so the automatic pause/resume feature can hiccup sometimes. They were a little confusing at first because there is no indicator light that stays on if the earbud is out of the case, so it took a minute to figure out that my media wasn't resuming sometimes because the earbud had turned its self off while sitting on my desk. The battery life isn't QUITE what they said. I get closer to 4 or 5 hours from a full charge, but the case keeps a long charge so really I can go days without plugging the case in.UPDATE: They can be a little finnicky when connecting to a PC. If the sound stop, just forget and re-pair
timestamp: Reviewed in the United States February 4, 2023
product_name: Jabra Elite 7 Pro - True Wireless Earbuds

title: 3.0 out of 5 stars Get or stick with the Jabra 75t/85t
author: Zed
content: Prior to writing this review, I've been waiting for the Jabra Elite 7 Pros to come out since it was announced. I was so excited, that I had placed an order on Amazon just a couple of weeks from when they were newly announced. However, when I initially placed an order, I never received it despite it saying it was delivered. However, after contemplating whether I should order it again and since I've been seeing mixed reviews from Amazon and from YouTube reviews, I decided to order again hoping it wouldn't disappoint. I'm coming from using the Elite 75t, so I can make a comparison here for those that are contemplating whether to upgrade. Here are a few major differences I've noticed:Pros:-Much smaller than the Elite 75t-Smaller Case than the Elite 75t-Touch Buttons (as with the Elite 75t)-Slight improvement in call quality; background noise and voice clarity is improved from mic.Cons:-Case is odd/strange to open/close-Fitment is great, but I believe the 75t fits better or at least feels more snug in the ear.-Although Jabra's focus was call quality for the Elite 7 pros, I believe they could have done better. Although the mic is more improved, it really didn't do a good job suppressing wind noise when driving with the windows half way up.Conclusion:I decided to return the Elite 7 Pros simply because I believe the Elite 75t are overall better:(1) Sound - sound on the Elite 7 Pros aren't as vibrant and lacking depth as opposed to the 75t; the 75t offer much more bass; however, the Elite 7 Pros do offer a slightly better clarity, which is geared more towards acoustic music, podcast, and making phone calls.(2) Fitment: fitment seems better as it feels snug in the ear and is comfortable to wear for long periods; overall, the Elite 75t has better fitment than the Elite 7 Pros.(3) The case: the case is easier to open as opposed to the Elite 7 Pros.(4) Mic: Sure, the mic does sound better on the Elite 7 Pros than on the Elite 75t; however, it's not an awe factor since it didn't live up to my expectations.(5) Price difference - for the price difference, the Elite 7 pros aren't worth it.Verdict: I'm going to stick to my Elite 75t while I search for other alternatives to use as a back up. Because of this reason, I have decided to return the Elite 7 Pros. For those that aren't coming from the Elite 75t, I would say go ahead and invest in the Elite 75t or 85t as it is much cheaper and get more for way less.

timestamp: Reviewed in the United States April 2, 2024
product_name: Jabra Elite 7 Pro - True Wireless Earbuds

title: 4.0 out of 5 stars Improved, but not perfect
author: Danny Underhill
content: I was excited to give these a try and see how they compared to my previous Jabra experience and compare to my other every days wireless buds I have. My previous experience with Jabra was not so good. The 65T's were excellent for sound and calls, but we're so big I had to return them as they would irritate and make my ears flame red. So when the new Elite Pro 7's came out and are smaller, I was once again excited. The Elite Pro's are smaller and more comfortable for sure. I still have some slight discomfort on one side, but that I attribute to my smaller ears.The sound on the Elite Pro is good. Low, mid, and high are all very acceptable for a small wireless ear piece. This is definitely a plus.Call quality in is great, quality out seems to be touch and go. I have had a couple of calls were the person on the other end stated they had real trouble hearing me. This is a little perplexing as the Elite Pro has 4 mics compared to some other brands that only have 3 and I never have issues with outbound call quality on those.Battery life and case charges are as advertised.ANC is ok, but not great. There are better ones on the market. The fact I have to go in and set up ANC is weird. Others come out of the box ready and do a great job. Not a huge thing here, but definitely different.Storage case is a bit odd in the fact it is nearly impossible to open one handed. Where other brands have a bit of a lip to grab and open, the Elite Pro's do not have such a defined lip making one handed opening difficult.Overall these are a good set and you won't be disappointed. Some pickier folks may not be completely thrilled, but they do deliver good sound and batttery. Overall I would recommend.
timestamp: Reviewed in the United States April 6, 2022
product_name: Jabra Elite 7 Pro - True Wireless Earbuds

title: 4.0 out of 5 stars I love these
author: Jimismycodename
content: Both the left and right earbuds can work individually, or as a pair, to simultaneously connect to 2 devices in about 4-5 seconds (about as long as it takes to get them out of the case and seated in your ear). They will switch between both devices seamlessly and automatically (watching a movie on an iPad and still hear the text alerts or rings from my phone). You can use one or both earbuds; start with two and put one away, start with one and add the second - they connect/disconnect immediately and flawlessly. The app is easy to use, and allows you to program the functions of the buttons of each earbud individually. After the initial setup, there is no need to use the app again, unless you want to tweak the equalizer for a specific type of media or sound. Sound quality is fantastic, especially for sub-$100 earbuds. My only criticism is the max volume - they get loud enough, but I don‚Äôt think they are capable of getting ‚Äútoo‚Äù loud (I don‚Äôt often want/need them to get ‚Äútoo‚Äù loud, but I would like to have the option to crank it up to 11 if I so chose). Some of that has to do with the media you may be watching, but I‚Äôve just noticed that I usually run these buds between 50-70% volume, whereas other buds I‚Äôve owned were comfortably used in the 30-50% volume range. Like I said, they are loud enough for me, so it should probably only be dinged half a star (another unnecessary option I might like to have here for my rating . . . not that I need it . . . I just like options for volumes and rating systems, I guess). They‚Äôre small, light, not gaudy, nor blingy - I absolutely love them. Highly recommended.
timestamp: Reviewed in the United States December 8, 2022
product_name: Jabra Elite 7 Pro - True Wireless Earbuds

title: 3.0 out of 5 stars Great personal sound in ear, but horrible mic
author: B45Havoc
content: Save your money if you choose to use these as a headset for both earbuds and phone calls. They are very decent airbuds with great sound and excellent noise cancellation if you listen to music or are watching a movie. However, this is why it gets such little stars. No one can hear you unless it‚Äôs absolutely quiet. Any sound around you is picked up and the people on the other end hear that and not you speaking. I had to remove them every time I have a meeting or a phone call, unless I am in my home in my office.If you own a Samsung phone get Samsung buds or if you own an iPhone only get AirPods. Apple doesn‚Äôt play nicely with other devices (shocker!!) I have bought cheap brands, and expensive brands to test so you don‚Äôt waste your time or money. Others fit in this same category. Great sound while listening to music or even you listening to phone calls and conferences, however if you have to speak same deal. This goes for Beats, Bose, JBl, and sein heiser, unless you are really willing to break open piggy and get their super high end earbuds that are a down payment for a car. The only ones I have found that work great on both an iPhone and a Samsung device are these:Sony WH1000XM series (cheaper then beats and Bose) and unfortunately are not earbuds. But the sound quality is the same as a Bose, best cancellation and crystal clear mic. It runs from 150 - 399.99. But try them and see for yourself. The M4 is the year before model, but just as good as the M5 and sadly still cheaper then AirPods.
timestamp: Reviewed in the United States August 30, 2023
product_name: Jabra Elite 7 Pro - True Wireless Earbuds

title: 5.0 out of 5 stars great product good features
author: JG
content: I have only had these Elite 7 Pro, about a week and a half. They are pretty easy to use. They are comfortable for pretty much all day wear (I do take them out and rub my ear once in a while, but never painful), and stay in place well. At least for me. I have to be active and on the move a good bit with my hands full for work while staying in touch by phone, so these Bluetooth earbuds are the ticket. I'm also pleased with the noise cancellation options which I'm often working in noisy to semi noisy environments and this cuts all that down to a very manageable level I don't believe they are actually hearing protection rated but they are certainly better then nothing in with a touch of a button your back to being able to hear and communicate with your surroundings/co-workers. I would like the option of full customization of controls which is far as I am aware is not possible there are some actions that I would like to be able to switch between right and left. I bought the Used in Good Condition level, but they arrived as far as I can tell Mint. I tend to have rather waxy ears. So far the design of the ear tips is easy to clean or does not seem easy to plug with waxy. The audio feedback is at a good volume level, and provides information without being invasive or disruptive of actual use. The multiple device pairing is a very useful feature I use all the time. I think they are a great product, I don't think I would spend full price for them, but if you can financially justify it or get them on sale, just buy them and enjoy (I have not tried any of the sister products, assume they are comparably great with their own flavors). Also I think I look like less of an idiot wearing these than those wearing Airpods, and you can put earmuffs straight over these (but may have mix results if you try taking calls with them on, I haven't tried it, and these are supposed to get -some- audio from your jaw)

timestamp: Reviewed in the United States November 14, 2023
product_name: Jabra Elite 7 Pro - True Wireless Earbuds

title: 5.0 out of 5 stars HiFi
author: Isaac
content: Apparently these are one of the flattest frequency response headphones on the market. That means the headphones sound close to how the audio was originally produced. The sub bass, richness, body, air...it's all very balanced. I very much prefer that and even use them occasionally for professional audio work. Others may prefer headphones with more high end or more bass or less harshness, rather than these very balanced ones.The details are good for Bluetooth, and you can hear lots of nuances and small details.Stereo imaging is lacking, which is normal for in ear headphones. They sound like a lot of the music is happening inside your head. I have Dolby Atmos on my phone, laptop, and desktop, which helps make the audio more immersive and sound 3D around you, instead of inside your head. Not all devices support Dolby Atmos, and it is not provided by or officially supported by the manufacturer.ANC works well enough for me. Their app allows you to basically calibrate the active noise cancelation to your unique ears. Once I did that, most outside sounds we're reduced to levels I can ignore. Low rumbly murmer like sound still passes through, although it doesn't bother me much.I love the hear through setting. I use them to listen to music while on the road now since I can hear the road around me - they sound much better than my cars sound system.Multi device connect is a little buggy - but very convenient. I can listen to content on my laptop, then answer a call on my phone without any troubles - usually. I suspect the troubles I do have arent the headphones fault - audio device handling can be finicky in general.Latency is moderately noticable. I'd say these headphones latency is about average with other Bluetooth devices. If you're watching TV shows, the audio plays a hair after actors mouths move. I usually ignore it and stop noticing the delay. If you're wanting headphones for gaming or playing instruments on your computer, I suggest wired headphones.If I broke mine on accident, I'd buy another pair.
timestamp: Reviewed in the United States February 1, 2023
product_name: Jabra Elite 7 Pro - True Wireless Earbuds

title: 1.0 out of 5 stars Awful all around
author: Kindle Customer
content: First it took almost 2 weeks for these to arrive, but that's on Amazon not Jabra.Overall these were pretty awful, I'm very disappointed after reading such glowing reviews on them. They are replacing a set of Samsung Galaxy Buds Live which without any doubt are by far the best fitting earbuds I've ever used in my life, and I've used a lot of different ones.My biggest complaint is that these make your ears/head feel very stuffy, similar to the feeling you get in an airplane when you want to pop your ears. I tried all three different size earpieces, the small were too small and they would fall out, and the medium and large made me feel stuffy. My Buds Live had an ambient mode that relieved this, although I never used it because they never felt stuffy. The closest thing on the Jabras is the pass through mode, but that's riddled with issues as I'll go into down below. No matter what I did I could not get over that feeling of discomfort, not pain, just discomfort and annoying.Sound: The sound on these is fairly mediocre, I'm really surprised that an almost $200 set of earbuds in 2023 could sound so mediocre. Highs were flat, the bass was no where as good as many of these reviews, and the soundstage was weird with a distinctive separate of instruments. With rock music I'd hear some instruments clearly only on the left, and others clearly only on the right, this isn't a soundstage, it's 2 separate stages on either side of the arena. Now maybe it was the music source (XM Radio), but listening to the same source on my Buds Live did not sound like this. Very distracting.ANC: My first question is if these really have any ANC at all. When setting them up I followed the directions to use them in a loud environment. Using the settings slider made NO difference at all in noise isolation. After they were setup, the ANC settings are weird, the slider seems to go through a set of white noise sounds, with the final one being no noise at all. This is different from the setting where you can actually add white noise to the sound. But no matter which ANC setting I put it on, phone calls always had the same white noise sound. I honestly believe 99% of the ANC on these is just the tight fit in the ear canal. I contrast these with my Buds Live which actually don't even go into the ear canal, yet still have halfway (not great) decent ANC.Just to add to the ANC debacle is how pass through mode amplifies sounds around me. My home office is in my remodeled basement next to my furnace. When pass through is on it actually greatly amplifies my furnace blowing and introduces this into the call. Actually it does this with pass through on or off, but I have to use pass through to hear my voice and in that case it amplifies it for both the person being called and myself.Reading through the reviews on here and other sites I see some of these issues are being discussed 1+ years ago and Jabra has not addressed them. That speaks to their customer service and I don't know if I want to invest in a company that doesn't address their issues.

timestamp: Reviewed in the United States July 7, 2024
product_name: Jabra Elite 7 Pro - True Wireless Earbuds

title: 5.0 out of 5 stars Excellent Product
author: Elaine
content: Let me start by saying, I have owned other over the ear and in-ear products and the Jabra Elite 7 Pro is a big step above the competition. The clear sound quality, advanced features, modern style, and intuitive interface really set this product out.FIRST IMPRESSION: When I first opened the packaging I was impressed with the textures and and design of the case and ear pods. Really giving them a modern feel. After first putting on the ear pods, the voice walkthrough to set the headphones up was easy and intuitive.SOUND QUALITY: Wow, this is where the Jabra Elite 7 Pro really stands out. It hits the highest highs and the lowest lows. I am used to the quality of in ear products being lower than over the ear, but that is not the case. The Bass feels very full and the treble has nice clarity. I played several different genres of music and every song allowed the sound quality to shine.USER INTERFACE: This is another aspect that stands out. I did not even have to pull out the manual to understand how to control my music. The controls are exactly what you would expect and the design is very thoughtful.STYLE AND COMFORT: When you wear the ear pods, you hardly notice them as the design is very sleek and modern. Once you fit the rubber piece correctly, I feel that you could wear these for hours without any discomfort. Jabra must have spent a long time designing these ear pods because they fit my ears perfectly.THE APP: In order to unlock the full potential of the Jabra Elite 7 Pro ear buds you really have to use the app. The developers of the app spent a long time adding numerous features that enhance sound quality, EQ, intensity of noise cancelling, and even custom fitting the ear pods to your ear.FINAL THOUGHTS: I would highly recommend this product to anyone looking for a quality in ear bud that delivers excellent sound quality on the go. You will not be let down with your purchase.
timestamp: Reviewed in the United States March 30, 2022
product_name: Jabra Elite 7 Pro - True Wireless Earbuds

title: 4.0 out of 5 stars I love these headphones.
author: Devin
content: These headphones are fantastic. I had a pair of Apple Pros before these and I have to say, I‚Äôm nearly as satisfied. There are some specific Apple ecosystem features you‚Äôll only get with AirPods, but you‚Äôll also being paying a premium to get. While I do miss those seldom used features, they were nice to have.However, what I don‚Äôt miss is the poor physical controls all AirPods have. These not only have excellent default controls but you can completely customize them if you prefer something else in the excellent Jabra Sound+ app. Being on a call or listening to music can have completely different controls, which is incredibly useful. Not only that, but you can tune these headphones to your preferences in said app by doing a simple hearing test or via the equalizer. Heck, you can even do both for a super personalized setup. You also get several white noise soundscapes in the app which is infinitely better than firing up a streaming service to get.The few glaring issues I have with these is that when a call is initiated or answered while they‚Äôre in my ears, I sound muffled to the person on the other side. If I take one out and reinsert it, the issue gets resolved. I cant stress enough how annoying this is. Also, when using multipoint bluetooth, there can be audio lag. Watching content can be hit or miss if you‚Äôre connected to your phone and say your pc at the same time. If I‚Äôm using them as headphones on my PC, i disconnect my phone.Overall, I‚Äôve really really enjoyed my experience with these headphones.
timestamp: Reviewed in the United States October 8, 2022
product_name: Jabra Elite 7 Pro - True Wireless Earbuds

title: 5.0 out of 5 stars Great earbuds!
author: fireproof1981
content: I use these both for running and in the gym,and they work great for both! The battery life is great, I normally only charge them once a week or even once 2 weeks even with heavy use. timestamp: Reviewed in the United States June 1, 2024
product_name: Jabra Elite 7 Pro - True Wireless Earbuds

title: 4.0 out of 5 stars I'm no audiophile...
author: Dale
content: and I understand the frustrations of my fellow shoppers what with multi-point not being a thing, but these really are solid earbuds. I grabbed a few knockoffs a while back but returned them because they were just terrible. The 7 Pros have a fit and finish to them that we've come to expect, as they should with a price of $200.I will say that I'm a bit befuddled with Jabra's insistence on cannibalizing their own product line. They've got the Elite 85t, Elite 75t, Elite Active 75t, Elite 65t, Elite Active 65t, Elite Sport, Elite 7 Pro, Elite 7 Active, and the Elite 3. I don't understand why they have so many different CURRENT versions. I can understand if they're older products being phased out, but to continue selling each at retail value, to say nothing of the manufacturing efforts seems foolish. As a consumer I had to spend an hour comparing all the different versions. Some have a better IP rating than others, some have 3 vs 4 microphones etc. Some vary in battery life by an hour, some are rated with their case's battery life. It's confusing to say the least.Regardless, I'm pretty happy with my purchase. Maybe one day they'll consolidate their lineup to 3-4 options for different consumer profiles. Until then, these will do.BTW, I've now done 3 firmware updates since I've owned these, and it's never been a problem. Just put them in the case, close the case and let the update finish. Let the light on the front stop blinking purple and you should be good. I hear multi-point is coming, but until then note that you CAN pair these to multiple sources‚Äîyou'll just need to disconnect them from the source they're connected to before connecting them to a new source. It's annoying, but functional.
timestamp: Reviewed in the United States November 27, 2021
product_name: Jabra Elite 7 Pro - True Wireless Earbuds

title: 2.0 out of 5 stars The most annoying $200 I've ever spent
author: Benbalam
content: When these things actually charge you can get about 4 hours of battery life with these if you turn off noise cancellation and hear-through modes.The last hour of their battery life though you will constantly hear each earphone individually crying "recharge battery" independently at different time periods. They can last like this for a whole hour before they decide to actually die. It is beyond annoying, you can't configure them to not make a noise, and an hour of it is just excessive. Either stop telling me or turn off please.Then when it comes time to charge sometimes they just will not charge in the case even when the case has a full battery and the lights on the earphones blink when you put them in the case. I lay the whole thing on the counter and let them charge and a 1/3 of the time when I go to pick them up again they are only 30% charged, which lets them last like an hour but you will hear the extremely annoying "recharge battery" sound the whole time which is unbelievably annoying.The noise cancellation and hear through modes don't deal with metallic noises very well. If you work with metal at all these things will put out a very high pitched extremely loud noise whether they're trying to cancel the metal on metal sound or pass it through. really makes them worthless for those kinds of jobs.There is also a wind noise that gets passed through these too if you're moving at speed with these in. I mow my lawn with them in and if there's any wind outside I'll hear the wind noise through the earphones regardless of what mode I'm inThis is probably the worst $200 I've ever spent on electronics.
timestamp: Reviewed in the United States March 12, 2024
product_name: Jabra Elite 7 Pro - True Wireless Earbuds

title: 3.0 out of 5 stars Almost perfect on paper, very disappointed in reality
author: Win
content: 1. Just to clarify, my review is about the 7 Pro. I don't know why but Amazon seems to put all Jabra's reviews together here. I've read quite a few before realizing that those were reviews for 75/85t.2. Like I said, the 7 Pro seems like the perfect pair I've been waiting for. ANC, transparency mode, single mode, multipoint, 6 mics with bone conductor, etc. Added those to great sound and sleek design, the 7 Pro is clearly the winner. Unfortunately, it doesn't.3. Let's start with ANC, well, what ANC? I have quite a few ANC tws but the Jabra Elite 7 Pro is one of the weakest ANC I've experienced with. I couldn't tell the difference between ANC on or off. Transparency mode, on the other hand, is excellent. I've been using Jabra tws since 65t and the transparency on their earbuds are always the best.4. Call quality, this is another area that 7 Pro failed me. I bought this earbud because I trust Jabra when it comes to call quality. To my surprise, everybody told me either I sounded like I was under water, driving with top down, walking outside in the wind, etc. Some people just told me they couldn't hear me at all. The weird thing was it only happened to the left earbud. When I used just the right, everyone can hear me just fine. At first, I thought it was a defect so I sent it back. Got another replacement and still have the same problem. The worst thing was when I used both earbuds, the call quality was still bad on the other end. To the point that I had to put the left bud back in the case, resume the call and people can hear me just fine.5. Everything else about the Elite 7 Pro was perfect as they said. Just the ANC and call quality on the left side that I couldn't use these buds as my daily driver. What a shame!
timestamp: Reviewed in the United States April 4, 2022
product_name: Jabra Elite 7 Pro - True Wireless Earbuds

title: 3.0 out of 5 stars Somewhat disappointing
author: Brian Douglas
content: The design of these earbuds are such that most of the mass of the bud itself is above the ear canal which, at least for me, means that as you move around they work their way out and if you don't re-seat them (about every 10 minutes) they'll fall out. It's fine if you're sitting in front of your computer but not at all useful if you're being active. The only way I found to combat this was to use the smallest silicon ear piece and seat them so far in my ear it was painful - also not helpful.I've seen reviews that rate the call experience with these earbuds really highly - especially in noisy environments. The sound app that comes with them even allows you to adjust the side tone which I was excited about. Sadly, none of it went very well. I could only get them to successfully work with my iPhone about half the time - mostly due to the mic. Often I could hear the other person but the mic didn't transmit on my end. I adjusted just about every setting in the sound app and even flashed the firmware - twice. I tried several times to get them to work with zoom too, but ended up throwing in the towel.The battery life and sound quality are very good however, so I'd say that if you're wanting to mostly sit still and get a lot of battery life out of your earbuds while not answering the phone, these are a decent choice. For me, I'll go back to the AirPods.
timestamp: Reviewed in the United States February 22, 2023
product_name: Jabra Elite 7 Pro - True Wireless Earbuds

title: 3.0 out of 5 stars Build quality is amazing, sound is average, ANC is bad, and connectivity is not good
author: S.L.
content: First of all, the packaging and build quality of these are quite amazing. I was impressed.However, the earbuds seem to work independently, while this could be a good thing, they don't communicate with one another properly. When I updated the firmware, the left earbud immediately stopped working. I followed the instructions and waited for the purple light on the case to stop blinking, and actually gave it additional time.The solution? I had to reset, repair, mess with buttons on each earbud, over 10 times before finally stumbling across a reddit article that said to take the 1 earbud out not working, put it in pairing mode, (hold for 3 seconds), and switch languages in the app. (I didn't have to do that, the app immediately recognized the left didn't have the firmware, but it took over an hour to get it working, unacceptable.The ANC and sound quality are not really that good in my opinion, and I'm far from an audio snob. It seems to just draw in white noise more than actually cancel out sounds.The drivers are tiny, 6mm, and while the music is acceptable, it's not good.The fit was comfortable, but for me, they seem to lock in too much pressure....resulting in my hearing my blood, pulse, and lots of just generally irritating sounds unless music is playing.Sadly I never got to test the call quality, I received them 10/17 at 2pm and have a return label printed at 8pm.To be fair, I think the company is probably a good one, the build quality, instructions seem very compassionate and thought out, but this isn't what I personally am looking for.
timestamp: Reviewed in the United States October 18, 2022
product_name: Jabra Elite 7 Pro - True Wireless Earbuds

title: 4.0 out of 5 stars Pretty Okay
author: Michael M.
content: This headset has a lot of good features and a couple bad quirks, overall it probably isn't worth the full price tag but I purchased them on the Amazon Renewed program for about 55% off, so worth it at this price point.Pros:Connects to multiple devices and switches between almost seamlessly.Buttons are actual buttons and not a touch sensor, so no random skips or accidental touchesCase is small and almost unnoticeable in your pocketIf the battery dies or you lose connection it saves the GPS locationHear through feature works like a hearing enhancerConsBattery life is okay, not an all day set but closeSound quality is lacking for this price point, competitors around half the price have a much richer sound, these have more of a neutral sound and the equalizer doesn't make a huge difference. They aren't bad by any means but if you are an enthusiast, look at other sets, you won't accept theseOverall these are a great set if you pick them up used, off of Amazon Warehouse or off of amazon renewed. At MSRP I would suggest looking at another set. With the price point I got and the ability to connect to multiple devices I plan to keep these for a while.

timestamp: Reviewed in the United States April 4, 2024
product_name: Jabra Elite 7 Pro - True Wireless Earbuds

title: 4.0 out of 5 stars They work great and sound great, with one small charging issue
author: Chad and Serra Hadsell
content: These are by far the best sounding and easiest to use wireless headphones that I've tried. Granted, the previous ones that I tried were all in the sub-$80 price range, so these better be good compared to those!Really though, they sound great and are easy to use. I love the multi-point support; being able to easily switch between my phone and computer without having to change any settings on any of the devices is great.The only issue that I have with these, and the reason I've giving them four stars instead of five, is that they have a weird charging bug that shows up every few days: I charge them until the LED turns green, but when I unplug them, the LED flashes red and the earphones tell me they're low on battery. It's as if the last few hours of charging just didn't do anything. But then sometimes I only have to plug them in for another minute or two and then it reports full battery. There's some sort of disconnect between the actual state of charge and system that reports state of charge to the user.
timestamp: Reviewed in the United States April 11, 2023
product_name: Jabra Elite 7 Pro - True Wireless Earbuds

title: 5.0 out of 5 stars Improvement from 75t active
author: Breanna
content: Having the Jabra Elite Active 75t previously, the Jabra Elite 7 pro stood out in a couple of ways.The run time was boosted from almost 4 hours to nearly 8 hours. When you include that both earbuds are available in mono-mode, you can get close to 16 hours out of these on a single charge. The claim of 15 min charging leading to 1 hour of playback is pretty accurate, but I did notice the case charge only lasted for one full recharge. The 75t's had at least two total charges for me. I didn't mind it when you include the mono-mode giving 8 hours on each bud. I just had to charge it on my drive home.The sound was also markedly improved between the two. I'll never claim to be an audiophile, but these are great when you need good music or podcasts during the workday. Call quality was the same between the two. I didn't make many calls, so I don't know the drain on the battery.A couple of other things to note:I used the mono-mode far more frequently because my work requires it, but while playing with ANC mode, there was no big difference compared with the 75t. Still pretty good, though, it'll quiet the din out of any room.The case feels bigger than the 75t. It still fits easily in the pocket, but accidentally opening it while pulling the case out is thankfully fixed.While Jabra claimed a better ear fit, I didn't experience it. It was the same for me, but I didn't have a big problem with the fit of the 75t. It'll fit for regular day wear, but 'hard activity' like running tends to fall out and require some readjusting.In general, this is an excellent option if you work in an office environment and would like some sound upgrade and would like to charge less. I highly recommend it. I purchased this item at a discount for my honest review.
timestamp: Reviewed in the United States March 17, 2022
product_name: Jabra Elite 7 Pro - True Wireless Earbuds

title: 5.0 out of 5 stars Finally something elite!
author: Quynn
content: I've now used these Jabra Elite 7 Pro for over a week and I've got some great thoughts on who they're perfect for, and the top features you can expect.I received this product at a discount in exchange for my honest review - and in my honest opinion these are some of the highest qualify true wireless buds on the market. I've now personally owned 3-4 other top of the line products and I can say with confidence I think these are the most well rounded.First off - Music and Sound Quality:These headphones along with being paired with their app give the user a very high quality, and fully customizable experience. Some people want to up the bass - these headphones have the deepness. Others want to hear more of the highs - you're covered there too with the customization. I personally think this is one of my favorite features. Movies, podcasts, and music all sound as they're supposed to without being too bass heavy, voice heavy, or lacking rich mediums.Call Quality - something that Jabra really focuses on with these headphones is the call quality and the technology built into the microphones. I personally don't see this as the strongest point of the headphones. Call quality is very good, and does exactly as you'd expect - however I wouldn't say it tops any charts in that department.Battery life - fantastic battery life and lives up to it's advertised amount of 35+ hours including the case.Active Noise Cancelling - Works very well with hear through. Something I know many people deal with including myself is that when we listen to active noise cancelling (ANC) headphones - it can almost cause pressure headaches as it feels like you're underwater or something. These are the first and only ANC headphones I've ever used where I truly can say I don't experience this at all.Overall these headphones are now my new favorite and I'll be recommending them to all friends and family. I think you'll end up loving these as much as I do!
timestamp: Reviewed in the United States February 21, 2022
product_name: Jabra Elite 7 Pro - True Wireless Earbuds

title: 5.0 out of 5 stars Got it for the mic quality, for calls
author: Metalcastr
content: I did a lot of research before getting these. Nearly all bluetooth earbuds have one inherent weakness that I wanted to overcome, and that's mic quality. Most earbuds have awful mic quality, and sound like a muffled mess that's hard to understand. But not these! I was also looking for a neutral sound profile with "good" audio quality, something I consider primarily good for calls, and then for general listening. Note that "good" is subjective, as everyone's preferred audio profile will be different, such as liking more of bass, treble, midtone, etc.Within the category of current generation 2022-2023 bluetooth earbuds, the mic on these is good, one of the best. If we compare it to another device category, such as USB microphones for PCs, then it's not great, but there are no great built-in microphones for bluetooth earbuds, it's just not available. So it's a comparison in the category in which it can compete, the bluetooth earbud category.Doing research online, and listening to mic sound samples on the Rtings website, these have some of the best mic quality for earbuds, they sound fuller than others, while not being too quiet or muffled. Comparing to a lot of other mics that don't pick up certain frequencies, that make voices sound hollow or "tinny", and hard to understand. I did not want to be the person hard to understand, so I got these.There are currently a few (and only a few) other bluetooth earbud sets on the market with good mic quality, do some research to see which ones have a good audio profile for you, both in the mic, and for general listening.

timestamp: Reviewed in the United States August 27, 2023
product_name: Jabra Elite 7 Pro - True Wireless Earbuds

title: 3.0 out of 5 stars Good for Most
author: Authorized Reviewer
content: Unboxing Experience is first. Keep in mind that I was provided this product t at a discount for my honest review. With that¬†being said I don't think what I got was the retail box. Grey box with no artwork or showcasing the brand. Once you dive inside its everything you expect. The headphones look beautiful and feel hefty in a good way. You also get ear cups for all sizes as well as a charging cable that will leave you wanting. You do have wireless charging with this pair so if you have one with your phones it will be a nice edition. Next is performance. Setting up with the proper app gives you plenty of control which is good because out of the box my units were high in the treble. Now everyone has their own opinion here but I feel this is where they were lacking. All the songs I use for testing just felt like they were missing something. The sound wasn't too low but no matter what I did there was never the right amount of bass. As for the noise cancelation they were there but in my testing not that effective. The one thing that was a cool factor but in reality a sore point on these headphones was the microphone. Using technology to use the vibration in your bones to help ended up coming up as poor audio experience for my callers on the other side. Lastly I have previous versions of these headphones and absolutely love them. These headphones were a miss and potentially not meant for me. They may be right for you which is why I rate them a 3/5. Most will buy these and love them and I do recommend them for the majority.
timestamp: Reviewed in the United States May 4, 2022
product_name: Jabra Elite 7 Pro - True Wireless Earbuds

title: 5.0 out of 5 stars Good replacement for my Elite 75t
author: Michael D
content: I lost my Elite 75T earbuds, and they've been discontinued. I almost pulled the trigger on the Elite 85T, but reading at the Jabra site that the earpiece doesn't go as far into the ear made me reconsider. After receiving the Elite 7 Pro's, I am very happy with the earbuds.What I am not happy about is the case. They changed it to be shorter and fatter. That in and of itself is not the concern though. With the old taller and skinnier case, I could open the top just by pushing the top towards the back, and it would open.With the short and fat design on the new case, it will not open like that, and they did not put any little tabs on the case in order to pry the top open, so I have to use a fingernail in order to open it.While this may not seem like a big deal, if the case is in my pocket when the phone rings, I do fumble in getting the earbud into my ear in time to answer, because it takes a little longer than before to open the case. Additionally, with no tabs it's difficult to know which side opens without looking at it which is not handy when driving.I am going to try and make some tiny tabs on the front using a tiny bit of Bondic which if it works, will help with not only lifting the top, but also in being able to open the case without looking at it.
timestamp: Reviewed in the United States July 19, 2023
product_name: Jabra Elite 7 Pro - True Wireless Earbuds

title: 4.0 out of 5 stars Great sound, nice form factor, mediocre noise cancellation
author: MaplewoodGeek
content: I have owned dozens of different ear buds, so I have a lot to compare these with.The sound is very good (for bluetooth, in-ear buds). The small size and weight helps keep them from falling out as easily as most other true wireless ear buds.There are really two areas that I am disappointed with these buds.The first is the lack of multi-point pairing. They can only connect to one device at a time. I have them paired with my phone, tablet, and laptop. They will automatically reconnect to the most recent device. To connect to a different device, I go into the bluetooth settings of the connected device and disconnect them. Then I click connect from the other device. I don't have to re-pair every time, but there are still extra steps. Jabra has promised to provide this feature in a future firmware update, but so far they had not done it.The second thing that disappoints me is the noise cancellation. With a good seal the ear buds provide decent passive noise cancellation. The active noise cancellation barely has any effect. While on a plane in flight I toggled the noise cancellation on and off and it made almost no difference. Maybe this will improve with future firmware updates.These are still my preferred ear buds, but if noise cancellation and multi-point pairing is important to you, look at something else or wait until these issues are fixed via firmware.

title: 5.0 out of 5 stars These are just great
