content: I‚Äôve gone through Jabra 65 and 75 series - both of which I liked - but ended up losing one of my 75 buds and decided to just upgrade to latest version. Have to say I Really like the 7 pro - it takes care of any deficiencies of the 75t model - mainly that you can use Either ear bud one at a time (love this as my hearing is better in my right ear - so when I‚Äôm monitoring meeting in background it‚Äôs nice to have just the left earbud in so I can still hear if someone asks me a question etc)Plus it‚Äôs just Awesome that you can have it synced to Multiple devices - I currently have it synced with my iPhone and laptop - and it‚Äôs smart about auto switching as needed.At first my only gripe was the case is a Little larger - and it‚Äôs a little harder to Open one handed - but after using it for awhile I don‚Äôt notice the larger size in my pocket - also I actually Like that it‚Äôs a little harder to open the case as it keeps the buds secure - in past sometimes the case opened Too easy and bud would fall out etc. One thing worried me is the case is so Smooth and slick easy to slip out of hands - so I actually Buffed the case to make it a little harder surface and easier to keep in hands securelyBut in any case - also the audio quality has really improvedThis is just a great setupI‚Äôm even purchasing a second one at the great deal pricing going on for a friend
timestamp: Reviewed in the United States December 6, 2022
product_name: Jabra Elite 7 Pro - True Wireless Earbuds

title: 3.0 out of 5 stars OK after January firmware update
author: B. Rogers
content: On day 2 and also day 12 of ownership, I had the right earbud stop working (all it would do is click at me when I held the button down) until I followed a factory reset procedure. After the reset, you have to re-do the pairing on each device that you use. So that's annoying.ANC is nonexistent. There is an ANC mode, but it just generates a very tiny bit of extra noise and cancels nothing compared to having ANC off.I did the firmware update on day 1, so these issues exist with the latest firmware at the time of me writing this review (1.5.0 released Dec 2, 2021). There's supposed to be a January update that adds multipoint, and I hope that also fixes these problems, but we're getting to the end of January and it hasn't happened yet. I'll update this review if a firmware update comes out soon enough for me to test and become confident in before my return window closes, otherwise this product is getting returned.Update: The 2.0 firmware came out the morning after I wrote this. I have it installed and multipoint is working well so far. There is no noticeable change to ANC. Stability could be better, but it's too early to be sure. I'll update this review in a week or so and increase the rating if there are no problems.Update: Working much better on 2.0, and I have found some conditions under which ANC does something. There's a certain background noise level you have to reach before ANC will make any difference. There are still some glitches, but they are not all the time anymore. I'm hoping for another update to improve it further.
timestamp: Reviewed in the United States January 27, 2022
product_name: Jabra Elite 7 Pro - True Wireless Earbuds

title: 3.0 out of 5 stars Awesome Quality, But the Firmware Isn't There
author: Fredrik Deboer
content: I got these to replace 75ts, and I have the same reaction: very strong audio quality, good noise cancelation, great battery life, superb physical construction, but repeated issues with connectivity are a major letdown. They sound quite good, even for someone who's into hifi equipment, call quality is not a problem for me at all (contra some other reviewers), and they feel so premium. But I have had several tear-my-hair-out frustrations with getting the earbuds to connect. Several times, I have suddenly lost connection to one earbud. This has seemingly happened in response to changing from one app to another (such as from my music app to YouTube), but it's hard to understand why that would affect a Bluetooth connection. The right earbud will work, but the left won't. Common fixes like turning on and off Bluetooth, unpairing the earbuds, and putting them into their case have no effect. The truly aggravating thing is that many of the troubleshooting suggestions I see involve pressing both buttons on the earbuds - but the left earbud is not connected, so it doesn't work! Each time I've eventually restored connection, but always just by messing around for ages and then finding they suddenly work again, so I don't have an effective workaround. It's quite frustrating, and given that I have similar problems with the 75ts I suspect that I didn't just get unlucky.It's a shame too because this is a very high-quality product with great sound for the price, and we badly need good alternatives to the Apples and Samsungs of the world. You might get these and never encounter the problems I have, in which case I think you're in for a treat. For me, I just hope I don't get another unlucky disconnect issue again.
timestamp: Reviewed in the United States December 10, 2021
product_name: Jabra Elite 7 Pro - True Wireless Earbuds

title: 5.0 out of 5 stars Jabra Elite 7 Pro Checks All the Boxes
author: NYY
content: Although I received this product at a discount in exchange for my honest review, I have always been anxious to try a set of Jabra earbuds, which have been included on every top ten list of best true wireless Bluetooth earbuds for as long as I can remember. The relatively new Jabra Elite 7 Pro appears to share flagship status and price point with the earlier Jabra 85T, but seems to offer several advantages, notably a smaller size and lighter weight, better water and sweat resistance, longer earbud and battery case battery life, and upgraded Bluetooth to version 5.2.I have to say that, among the earbuds that I have tried thus far, at various price levels, the Jabra Elite 7 Pro are quite comfortable over long periods and, more importantly, I have less fear of them falling out with head movement due to their light weight and tight fit. Moreover, the sound and call quality are excellent and the active noise cancellation (ANC) is quite good, no doubt helped along by the close fit of the earbud and the ANC control offered by the Sound+ app provided by Jabra. A single tap of the left earbud enables the HearThrough function to disable ANC for conversation, also controllable through the app. The factory EQ tuning is set for more natural sound reproduction but can be customized in the app if you want or need more bass.Battery life, especially with ANC on lives up to the specified 8 hours, with rapid recharge available for quick extension of the listening session. The inclusion of Alexa and Google Assistant as well as mono mode and multipoint connection are added pluses, along with the compact case.All in all, the Jabra Elite 7 Pro checks all the boxes for a high end, albeit somewhat expensive, Bluetooth earbud and I would strongly recommend consideration for purchase.

timestamp: Reviewed in the United States January 27, 2023
product_name: Jabra Elite 7 Pro - True Wireless Earbuds

title: 5.0 out of 5 stars Big Sound in Little Ear Buds
author: Phemsley
content: The Jabra Elite Pro Ear wireless earbuds have surpassed my expectations! Ear bud fit is always a problem for me, and I've found most of the small wireless earbuds will not stay in my ears, especially if I'm the least but active. These earbuds slide in smoothly and stay put! Jabra offers 3 different sizes of ear fittings, and the mediums that come with it fit perfectly for me.The setup of the earbuds is very straightforward, download the Sound+ app and walk through the steps. The app will show you how to use and customize the different tap settings, and also run any needed software updates. Very intuitive and a nice introduction as you get started using the new earbuds. There is also a "Find my Jabra" setting that will use location tracking to keep track of the location. Neat feature if this ever does fall out of your ears!Now that we've discussed the fit and setup, let's get to the sound. The sound quality of these is amazing. They have the option to enable noise cancelling, and to easily disable it by tapping the left earbud in cases where you want to hear outside of the earbuds. The sound is also very clear even when using one ear bud, which I often do because I'm multi-tasking. The app has preset equalizers or you can customize your own.I'd highly recommend the Jabra Elite Pro Ear buds as a great alternative to other higher priced wireless earbuds and I'm very happy I've found them as they have greatly enhanced my music listening experience! I received this product at a discount in exchange for my honest review.
timestamp: Reviewed in the United States February 15, 2022
product_name: Jabra Elite 7 Pro - True Wireless Earbuds

title: 4.0 out of 5 stars Great sound, great fit, UNCOMFORTABLE ear tips (get replacements when ordering!)
author: Thomas M.
content: These are all around amazing, from sound to build quality and EQ tweaking in the Jabra Sound+ app they are hard to beat at this price point. However, the included ear tips aren't well designed and can bite into the ears over long periods of time. Instead of being gently curved back, the tips have a sharp rubber edge that can create a painful groove in the ear.This is an EASY FIX. You can find replacement ear tips for this model as low as $4.50. DON'T get generic replacements as these buds have an unusually small tube for the ear tips and generics will likely fall off. As long as you order model specific ear tips with this you won't have any problems.NOTE: These are practically identical to the Jabra Elite 7 Active in terms of hardware, order whichever is cheaper/on sale. Also the Elite 7 Actives won't stay in better because the rubber portion is on the outside of the bud, not the part that actually touches your ear. Both models have the same IP57 water resistance rating so neither has an edge on the other.

title: 4.0 out of 5 stars Good, but not Jabra 75t good
author: Randall B.
content: I bought the Jabra Elite 7's after running my Jabra 75t's into the ground. It seemed like a good logical step after how much time I had put into my previous earbuds. I'll say that in terms of sound quality and overall earbud quality goes, the Jabra Elite 7's are great. But the little things that I didn't realize mattered have kept me from giving it a 5 start review. First off, and I know it may seem like nitpicking, the charging case doesn't have a groove for opening it. You might thing "who cares?" But I can tell you, when you're sweaty from a workout, or trying to handle the case with one hand, it's almost impossible to open it. With how frequently the ear buds are in their case, this starts to add up to an inconvenience. I've also noticed that in a day full of meetings, the connectivity is hit or miss with my Mac. Sometimes, I have no issues, but other times the ear buds seem to cycle between trying to enable the microphone and listening, which causes neither to work.Overall, the connectivity issues and the case build definitely make this a bit of a downgrade from the Jabra 75t's. But the noise cancelling and audio quality make up for it.

title: 2.0 out of 5 stars Constantly disconnects, no user manual
author: Michael
content: So let me just start off by saying that I paid for NEW earbuds, and I'm starting to wonder if what I was given were actually refurbished. There wasn't even a user manual included. I pulled the whole package apart searching for ANY kind of setup instructions and there were none, there was not a single piece of paper in the box. After finally getting them to sync up with my devices, I have to say that the sound quality and battery life were decent... That said, good sound quality and battery life do not make up for the headache these things have caused me on a daily basis for the past several weeks. They will constantly disconnect at random intervals for seemingly no reason, and when I do finally manage to get them to reconnect after fighting with them for ten minutes, only ONE earbud (the left one) will actually turn back on, no matter how many times I reset them OR my laptop. I had to stop trying to use them with my phone altogether because they simply wouldn't connect most of the time, sometimes they wouldn't even show up in the list of devices and on the off chance I DID get them to sync up, it was like pulling teeth to get them to sync back up to my laptop afterward, even after I removed them from my phone entirely. Overall, not worth the headache. I was lead to believe these were much better quality but I'm guessing all those reviews were written by people who only used them for a couple days at most because it's been nothing but a hassle since I got them. Even my cheapest ear buds sync up faster and easier than these do. I am not willing to tear my hair out over this just for a couple extra hours of battery life.

title: 4.0 out of 5 stars Jabra Elite 7 pro - Great Headphones for phone and Audiobooks
author: Bike Enthusiast
content: I picked up the Elite 7 pros for their water resistance (ip57). I use them running, trail running, and bicycling. They've stood up well. I have replaced the earbud tips with comply foam. Two things you should be aware of. With the Comply foam tips, this has almost completely removed the need or benefit of the ANC as i can hear no difference in blocked sounds with the Comply tips. Also, the sound design seems to emphasize mid range. The sound is just not terribly full. The upside to this is that if you are an audiobook listener, you will absolutely love these IEM's. Oh, and just to be clear, I do feel the comply foam tips have actually improved the bass from the stock tips. They do stay quite secure. I've never had them work themselves out and with the Comply's, I've never had to adjust them during a run. When on the road, I use the 'hear through' which works quite well, and when off road, i just leave the ANC/Hear through off which does increase the battery time.Enjoy.

title: 2.0 out of 5 stars Good but not worth the price if you need the microphone
author: J Hancock
content: I bought these as an upgrade for a much cheaper ($49) set that I use for work and music. First impression was good, they fit well and the battery life was great and it solved my to biggest issues with my others and the sound is amazing but that's where it went downhill for me. These earbuds introduced 3 new issues that I've never had with my cheaper ones. 1st, the microphone is unusable for work calls as you some distant and in a barrel. I know I can't expect perfect quality from earbuds but these are horrible compared to my others. 2nd is the multipoint switching. I like to have my buds on my laptop as primary and phone secondary so that I can listen to music between calls and when I start a video call the audio automatically switches to my laptop. With these buds even trying the instructions to connect my laptop first My phone always overtakes the connection. There have been several times in the middle of a video conference call that my microphone and sound completely cuts out because of a notification on my phone. 3rd is the latency of the sound for video. Both on conference calls and watching videos and clips on my phone the picture is always out of sync.For troubleshooting I have installed and re-paired to my devices multiple times and changed multiple settings and I can't overcome these issues. After looking at multiple online forums it seems to be firmware issues so I re-loaded the firmware by changing the voice assistant language but that didn't help either.Bottom line, if you want them for music only I recommend but if you need to use the microphone I would say pass. I've just ordered another brand to test and will be returning these since earbuds this expensive shouldn't come with these problems and I shouldn't need to jump through hoops to get them to work.

title: 4.0 out of 5 stars Excellent ear buds..great sound, super comfortble
author: J MacG
content: Great set of ear buds. I have had Jabra 75t for the past 2 years and after I thought I had lost them (found them later) I purchased the Elite 7 Pros. If you're on the fence...just buy them, you wont regret it!

title: 2.0 out of 5 stars Great sound. Good ANC. Terrible audio sync when watching videos.
author: MrrQuackers
content: Firstly, they sound fantastic, great sound all around and the app does a really neat set up feature where it uses your specific ear to adjust the EQ. It uses buttons instead of touch sensors which isn't too bad since the button are nice and easy to press (so you're not jamming the bud in your ear when trying to press). They do not offer high fidelity like LDAC, heads up there if you're looking for superior audio codecs.The absolute worst part and the reason I returned these for much better earbuds was the audio sync issue when watching videos. Whether you're using the multipoint feature or not, if you try to watch any video on your Windows computer (YouTube, Instagram, etc.) the audio will fall out of sync and get worse the longer your watch. The only way to fix it would be to pause or back up the video over and over until it was back in sync (only for it to go out of sync the longer watched, rinse and repeat).The kicker was when I contacted Jabra they offered no solutions and simply said that they DO NOT test their products with computers. When I pressed on the issue and stated the multipoint feature. They claimed this was meant for someone who has a work phone and personal phone, or a phone and a tablet. When they said thet I responded that their own marketing video showing off multipoint where it shows a woman using the feature with a Windows Surface Laptop and her phone. After that they shifted the goal post and just stated that it may work but it is not supported.After this I returned these earbuds due to the terrible audio sync issue and the absolute worst support from Jabra. I ended up getting the Technics EAH-AZ60 and have never been happier. They do everything the Jabra's do plus offer LDAC and no audio sync issues. They also have touch sensitive controls that works great (no buttons).

title: 5.0 out of 5 stars I have 3 different sets, all good.
author: R. Ruiz
content: I have a few sets : the 7 pro, 7 active, and 3 true active. They aren't perfect. Sometimes one starts playing a second before the other. When the active or pro are wet they still work fine, but the mic is muffled for a phone call until they dry. Of the 3, I think the active is the the most comfortable. You wouldn't think that little rubberized part would make that much difference but it does with long hours of use. The noise canceling is okay, but not great and for that reason I think the 3 is the best value unless you need it to be water resistant or want the "okay" noise canceling. Overall I think they are all good. I have NOT had anyone ask me if I was on bluetooth or say they couldn't hear me on any of them (except when wet). I gave the 3 to my son and alternate the other 2 throughout the day when the batteries die. (Side note the 3 doesn't use voice "2 devices connected" "pairing" for example). The last feature I like is the "battery low" warning is about an hour before the battery is dead on the 7's. I'm not sure on the 3.I also wanted to add that the 7's can connect with 2 devices at a time. The 3 cannot.

timestamp: Reviewed in the United States March 11, 2022
product_name: Jabra Elite 7 Pro - True Wireless Earbuds

title: 2.0 out of 5 stars The Elite 7 Pro not impressive
author: Jaxly
content: Coming from Jabra elite 75t, which has a very flat and narrow sound, the elite 7 pro is a nice upgrade. I needed mid-level earbuds with multiple points connection, so I bought the elite 7 pro. It took 20 min to update and install the newest firmware with the expectation for top-level sound quality and mid-level ANC. The fact is that the 7 pro earbuds are nowhere near the expectation.With some fancy features like comfortable to wear, multipoint connection, in-ear detection, and sound profile personalization, the 7 pro earbuds are very friendly to use. However, the sound quality and ANC are very disappointing.The sound quality of 7 pro earbuds is simply not comparable to the Bose qc earbuds, and it is not even as good as the 40 bucks Fiil T1XS. The EQed T1XS has way richer, punchier, more dynamic, and more layered sound than the 7 pro earbuds. The sound of the 7 pro is very light and soft even after tweaking with all the EQ settings. To have a better idea about the sound quality of T1XS, it is slightly less clear than the apple airpods, which is not known for its sound quality.If you want TWS earbuds with at least mid-level ANC, skip the 7 pro. The ANC of the 7 pro is strange. It's like changing the natural environmental noise to a hybrid of artificial and natural noises. It reduces the environmental noise a little bit, but it doesn't go silent at all.For this 160 to 200 USD price range, you may expect at least the above-average sound quality or ANC. Unfortunately, the Jabra elite 7 pro does not meet either criterion. I would rather go to more expensive Technics AZ60, the Sennheiser MTW3, or Sony 1000xm4 with the highly-rated sound quality and mid to top ANC, than pay for this already high price for earbuds with nothing. I wouldn't recommend Bose qc earbuds unless the bulky case, kind short battery life, slow connection, and dependent left earbud are not issues to you. If you need half in-ear tws earbuds with the best ANC and top sound quality, the qc earbuds are still the best choise.

title: 5.0 out of 5 stars Surpasses AirPods
author: victoria
content: I ordered like 8 different earbuds and this is the only one I didn‚Äôt return. They have easy connection to iPhone. Once they are pairs for the first time, all u have to do is put an earbud in and it will connect. They have wireless charging which is convenient since plugging earbuds in has been an issue for me. The app has EQ customization, not revolutionary but still nice to have. The app also allows for the customization of the noise cancelation; you can decide what audio frequencies to filter out. These earbuds stay in my ear much better than AirPod pros imo. The best feature is the customization of the accessibility button on each earbud. You can make the button do anything u want independent from each other. There are also different button settings u can make for different scenarios like being on the phone or not. I personally loved that u can mute the call w a click of the earbud (this is convenient because I get a lot of wind noise from longboarding), I have not been able to find an earbud w as much accessibility as these.

title: 5.0 out of 5 stars Sporty , slick power sound
author: T. D
content: I loved this perfect fit sporty ear buds that has a power house sound. Just the sheer sound quality and the way they fit my ears , made me say "wow". I have had couple of ear buds from big brands and have not been happy the way they fit and the features they provide. This ear buds caught me by surprise on all front. The Noice cancellation and hear through features are really exciting. I get the sound quality comparable to other top brands with this additional features which is worth the price and recommendation. The app to support this ear buds is also very well made . It is very intuitive and get to the various functions very easily without much thinking or effort to click around. Battery life on the buds is pretty good too. It lasted me for almost whole day of listening without putting it back in the case. I listened for an house for my run and then took it out and then tried it again on similar cycle through out the day and yet it was not discharged . Only late at night it indicated on low battery. Taking a call on this buds was easy too and the background noise cancellation was very good and the other caller confirmed the sound quality from microphone to be loud and clear. I would certainly recommend this headphones in this short usage I have had and look forward to more music time with it in the busy life. I received this product at a discount in exchange for my honest opinion.

title: 5.0 out of 5 stars Great listening and talking experience
author: Steve
content: I have been using earbuds for a long time. I have many many pairs of earbuds, but when I heard of the features of the Jabra Elite 7 Pro, I knew I had to have a pair. The things that most interested me were the multi-point connection and the Jabra MultiSensor voice technology. I use two phones on a regular basis, one Apple phone and one android phone. And it works great with these headphones. I can switch between them seamlessly. The voice calling is great as well, better than any of the other headphones I have used. I also have come to rely on the adjustable Active noise cancellation. Ordering lunch, just tap the button and you can hear what‚Äôs going on around you. Tap again and shut everything out while you enjoy lunch and a podcast without having to hear all the noise going on around you. With the Bluetooth 5.2 connection I can watch my YouTube videos or catch up on a TV show without the lip synch delay experienced by headsets using the older generation of Bluetooth. Like I said, I use these a lot, downloaded the app and used it to customize my experience as well as software upgrades. Fantastic product all around. From the comfort to battery life, I am very glad I got to use these headphones. They really have improved my daily life, and now go everywhere with me. I was very lucky to have been given the opportunity to receive this product at a discount in exchange for my honest opinion.

title: 3.0 out of 5 stars Poor battery life, mic is VERY picky on direction
author: J. S. Schlatter
content: I've owned these now for 6 months and swap back and forth between them and Samsung Buds +.First the good news, the controls and sound customization are great. The buds also have good sound with slightly better bass that the buds+. I also like that you can have 2 devices connected at the same time, so I can use for both my cell and PC.Now for the bad news: using these for conference calls is frustrating. If the buds are sitting perfectly in your ear, people say they sound great. If they rotate even slightly, people say they can't hear me even if I'm talking quite loud. The other disappointment is battery life when using as a headset/mic. I get at most 2 hours out of them with pass through and noise cancelation turned off. By comparison, the buds+ are going strong after 4 hours. I admit I'm on calls a LOT most days with almost no breaks to recharge between calls. My final frustration is that they don't fit my ears well and will eventually fall out if not reset fairly often.Overall, I was disappointed in the Jabra Elite 7 Pro and would not purchase again.

title: 5.0 out of 5 stars Definitely an Elite Product

content: **I received this product at a discount in exchange for my honest opinion.Straight out of the box, these earphones look slick and well built. I recommend downloading the app before inserting them into your ears. They immediately walk you through the pairing and set up process. From the high notes and the deep bass boost that is available, you will find the setting that best fits your listening preferences or you can use the preset options that the app offers.Overall, I am extremely happy with the purchase and will enjoy using the Jabra Elite 7 Pro in the future. #JabraElite7Insiders

title: 2.0 out of 5 stars They work great for a little while
author: The Wanderer
content: I will start by saying that I love these things (when they work). They are solid and have great sound and battery life (when new). I bought a second pair right after buying and trying the first pair, as I work in an extremely remote location and need redundancy. Both pairs stopped charging fully after less than a year. Online it says it's not the earbuds but the case that is the problem, and tons of people are having this problem. There is a reset capability with the case by plugging it in and leaving the lid open. That worked briefly on the case that completely stopped charging, giving it partial functionality, but both cases now will only charge the buds a small amount and its random how much charge they get. As soon as I put the buds in they start telling me the battery is low, but it is apparently just a glitch as it will stop telling me that after a bit and keep working for a random amount of time, then they just die. it could be 30 minutes or three hours.They also just started disconnecting randomly after a while and they seem to confuse Spotify for some reason at times and just keep pausing it over and over making it impossible to listen.Good product out of the box, but seriously flawed. I don't understand how they just keep making them like this.

title: 1.0 out of 5 stars DON'T BUY these. Unreliable. Frequently drops BT connections. Google Assistant integration is 50/50.
author: LvgZombie
content: See the headline. I don't recommend these. Although the sound performance (including ANC) is excellent when the buds are working ... they are usually buggy and _not_ working, most of the time. They're just not worth the hassle.This is my 2nd pair of Elite 7 Pro. First pair I bought a year ago started exhibiting all of the same problems mentioned in the headline.What's worse: after unpairing the earbuds from my device, doing a factory reset on the earbuds, and then setting 'em up again using the Jabra Sound+ app ... after a day or so, the Sound+ app will no longer "recognize" the earbuds. Although the earbuds might be paired (and working) with the device, upon opening the Sound+ app it will display instructions like "Remove earbuds from the case and pair them to your phone" ... as if I was setting up the earbuds for the first time.Also, somehow the earbuds very frequently seem to "lose" their interface or connection with Google Assistant. Within the Sound+ app, you're given a choice of either "Amazon Alexa," "Google Assistant," or "Android Default." I preferred to use the "Android Default" setting for the physical button Google Assistant prompts -- meaning, I would double-press the left earbud button. Using the "Android Default" setting allows you to adjust your connected media device's volume by pressing and holding the right earbud button (increase volume) or left earbud button (decrease volume). Well, these earbuds would go maybe a day on that "Android Default" setting before they stopped responding to the "left button double-click" prompt for "Google Assistant."Bottom Line: I've tried using these on 4 different Android devices, running Android 0S 9 thru 13. Eventually, these Elite 7 Pro earbuds exhibit the exact same problems. My bad experiences with both the 1st and 2nd sets of this model has turned me off from buying any Jabra earbuds in the future.

title: 2.0 out of 5 stars Great Sound, Great Fit, Horrible Microphone
author: John
content: I'm on a quest to find a replacement for my old Samsung Galaxy Buds I left in a motel room. So far it hasn't been good. I have an iPhone 14 Pro Max, I have a pair of Airpods but they just don't fit me right, they fall out and the sound is poor. I prefer the earbud style too. After finding the new Samsung Buds aren't iPhone compatible I decided to look at Bose and Jabra. It came down to the Jabra Elite 7 Pro and the 85T, with the 7 Pro winning mainly due to size and good reviews.I received them, charged them and downloaded the Jabra app. They fit perfectly with the installed gels and were very comfortable. The app tuned them for my hearing, so I turned on some music and was pleased with the sound quality. The EQ needed no adjustment, they sounded pretty darn good just the way they were. I don't need ANC so I never tested it. I received a phone call and that's when the ugly came out. One minute the caller could hear me, then I just went away and they couldn't hear a word. Both buds, one bud, no difference. I blew it off and figured it must have been a fluke. Later I received another call and the exact same thing happened, except worse. The microphones worked for a few seconds then just stopped, then they'd come back on again but only for a few seconds. So, during the call I put them back in the box and packed them up to return them. The search for a good earbud continues.

title: 2.0 out of 5 stars Bad noise cancellation with sacrificial sound
author: Ethan
content: I was really excited getting a pair of these from Prime Day sales. Shipping was great and package undamaged. However, I noticed several disappointing things about the earbuds. This is apparently common for android users, but the audio has a more than a half second delay. If you're listening to music it's not that big of a deal. When watching movies or playing games you notice the audio isn't in sync with what's on the screen which kills the experience. Sometimes in-between listening, the audio between earbuds aren't perfectly matched which sounds like you're hearing an echo. Another thing I don't like is the app. It has some interesting features, but the equalizer is so frustrating. You think you can raise the treble and bass as high as you like, but adjusting one causes the other to decrease in sound quality. Meaning you have to sacrifice having good bass, mids, or treble for the other while not capable of having all due to the speaker's limitations. No matter how you adjust them, it still sounds like listening to tin speakers. My final issue is with the mic. On phone calls, I been hearing a lot of remarks from people I talk to about there being background noise while I'm speaking. I tried adjusting noise cancellation and side call, but the static noise never fully went away. Overtime, the audio from me and the caller become distorted as though the earbuds are gradually dying when on 100% charge. I haven't had this problem with my $50 wired earbuds with a cheap $7 mic built into the cord. These costed more than my headphones and earbuds in base price and it failed to be anything better than either of them. The only thing you're really buying these for is being wireless and nothing more. Even though I'm sure there's better wireless earbuds out there if these have so many issues.

title: 5.0 out of 5 stars I love these earbuds!
author: Monica
content: I received this product at a discount in exchange for my honest review. Let me tell you about these earbuds! They fit my ears perfectly with the smallest earbud covers. It uses the earbuds microphone to allow you to hear the outside noises and it sounds more enhanced too. I love that! The battery seems to last a long while. I haven't recharged since I received them. Oooh! Also the earbuds have an app called sound+ where you can control the music equalizer amongst other things. My favorite thing about the sound+ app though is the find my Jabra feature. title: 3.0 out of 5 stars Good, but not quite the replacement of the 75t that I had hoped for
author: Jeffrey J.
content: I had the Elite 75t before and they were my favorite bluetooth headphones. There was basically no delay when watching any video from any app on my phone. I noticed other mainstream headsets failed to sync specifically with TikTok videos, resulting in noticable lag. And now I'm devastated that the Elite 7 Pro also fails this TikTok challenge, though slightly better than some competition. Recently, my 75t had no sound coming out of the right ear so I figured I'd be safe upgrading to the new and supposedly imporved Elite 7 Pro. Truly saddened by the Elite 7 Pro not meeting up to the apparently demanding audio synchronization that TikTok has on seemingly every other bluetooth headphone except probably AirPods for iPhones and the now 2 year old Elite 75t. Even the active noise cancellation seems better on the 75t and it wasn't even an expected feature until a surprise update brought it. Feels like Jabra is relying more on the ear piece suppressing sound through natural passive noice cancellation that seems more intense than the previous model. RIP Elite 75t. I can only hope future updates can make the Elite 7 Pro a true successor. I'd still recommend the Elite 7 Pro for great mic call quality, now allowing either earbud to be used independently which the 75t didn't have, the official IP rating, wireless charging case, and great battery life.

title: 5.0 out of 5 stars Really nice portable speaker for the price. Solid buy!
author: Bruce C
content: Needed a new portable speaker for the home setup and once I saw that Beats (read: Apple) came out with the new Beats Pill, I bit the bullet and purchased one.First things first, the unboxing experience and the design of the speaker is quintessentially Apple. Speaker has a nice heft to it and the design of the speaker is really nice, with the angled design, and the speakers facing you.If you are in the Apple Ecosystem, this speaker was made for you as it connects to your iPhone the minute you turn it on with a very satisfying screen animation. I'm told you can easily connect with an Android product too but I didn't have one in hand to test out how easy it was.The sound quality of this speaker is really great for its size, living up to the Beats name, filling the room with punchy bass and crystal clear sound. Rated IP67 meaning it is dust and water resistant, so you can feel confident taking it to your next beach party or when you are traveling. Battery life of this thing is stated at a whopping 24 hrs. I'll definitely be testing that claim, but if true, is completely mind blowing.But what sets this speaker apart, and one of the main reasons why I bought it, is that it also doubles as a speakerphone!!! I can connect this badboy to my laptop, and take crystal clear Teams calls with it all day at work. And when I'm done with my calls, since it is connected to my laptop via USB-C, I can listen to lossless music on Apple Music. Mind...blown!Run, don't walk, to buy this awesome speaker!!

title: 3.0 out of 5 stars Good design, but bass distortion
author: Daniel
content: The new pill looks awesome, and built extremely well... The tone when pairing emits a very low end bass note that gets you excited for the performance expected from Beats... However, with this being said, the performance is only half of what I hoped... the programmed sound processing limits using an external eq as boosted bass significantly drops the volume at each note, which is sad because pill doesn't have an eq in its app at all.... the sound you get between 40 percent and lower is where this shines, mids are clear and neutral, highs are clear and crisp without any harshness, and there is a slight amount of low end at lower volume, but past halfway volume and the bass distorts and the programming takes over to then roll off the bass and then it's mostly just mids and highs.... They seriously could've added a passive radiator to the back of this thing and then would have something here.... All this, and the package arrived with the box already opened.... not too excited about my purchase....

title: 4.0 out of 5 stars Bass Heavy
author: Geomancer
content: As you can probably tell from the product description heavily focusing on the subwoofer, you won't be surprised to learn that this speaker is very bass heavy. That's fine for songs that complement that kind of sound, but is a determent to anything else. For example listening to an audio book it doesn't sound very good and I actually prefer my phone's built in speaker or a regular set of headphones. There is no EQ feature, even if you download the Beats app. Speaking of the Beats app, it doesn't really have any use. It will tell you battery life, and remind you what the controls are, but that's it. The "one touch connect" feature did not work, I had to manually connect in my Bluetooth settings (Android, Samsung Galaxy S20 FE).For controls there are four buttons. A power button, multi-function button (play/pause/next/previous), volume down, and volume up. They are the same color as the speaker, do not light up, and are difficult to see. I initially had some trouble turning it off because you have to hold the power button. However if you don't hold it long enough it just gives you a battery life indicator, hold it too long it goes into pairing mode. You have a 2-3 second window between those two functions to actually get it to turn off.Volume wise, it does get pretty loud. Loud enough to hurt if you're nearby. Bass of course travels well and far, be aware that you will annoy your neighbors if your outside with the volume up. Perhaps even at a mid volume because it is so bass heavy. Not great for apartments because of that, at least if you don't want to be that annoying neighbor.If you have two of these, you can sync them together either to just make them even louder (why would anyone want that? It already hurts at max volume), or as a stereo pair.For the price, I would have preferred a speaker with a more balanced audio profile. For tracks that do emphasize bass though it does sound pretty good. Overall I would classify my annoyances other than the sound profile as minor.
timestamp: Reviewed in the United States June 28, 2024
product_attributes: Color: Matte BlackStyle: PillPattern: Without AppleCare+

title: 4.0 out of 5 stars Not bad for the price
author: M.J. Shearer
content: I own a plethora of bluetooth speakers, one even costing 10x this one. But, for a small portable form factor, this pill doesn't sound half bad. It is definitely not my favorite in the sound quality department, but the portability factor makes it a keeper. Right now, I'm testing it on my kitchen window sill and it provides me with adequate sound whilst I rustle up grub for the fam. Highs are clear, mids are punchy, bass is present but it won't knock your socks off. If you're looking for a balance between portability and sound quality, then this might be your ticket at 150$. BUT, if you want better sound quality, save up another 100 bux and you can find a larger (even much larger) speakers that will SA-MOKE this one, but, you WILL sacrifice portability. One issue I found with this speaker is that the rubberized texture on the back is a dust and animal hair magnet. (Two cats and two GSD's...you GSD owners out there know the struggle) It will not wipe clean with your hand, but a very damp paper towel works like a charm.
timestamp: Reviewed in the United States July 10, 2024
product_attributes: Color: Matte BlackStyle: PillPattern: Without AppleCare+

title: 5.0 out of 5 stars Beats pill returned with an amazing and sleek speaker for IOS/ android
author: Alan
content: This is a very small and compact speaker, but for its size, it packs a serious punch. It's comparable to the JBL Flip 6. Sure, that speaker has even better bass, but this more complete package for its price, with speakerphone and in my opinion, more sexy design.-The bass is great, and the overall mid and high range is excellent, but I wouldn‚Äôt say it‚Äôs the best among portable speakers. This is overall a very bass-heavy speaker. I only own the black one, but I‚Äôm interested in trying out other models when I get a gold one (because it‚Äôs sexy af).-This is definitely the best-looking and sleekest portable speaker. It‚Äôs minimal, smooth, and easy to carry around. Sure, for the price, you can argue that you can get a ‚Äúbetter‚Äù speaker, but what this speaker offers is a well-rounded package: nice sound with great bass, goes well with home decor without sticking out, and minimal with a beautiful design. It's especially easy to access if you're an Apple user. Speakerphone has decent clarity and nice usages in times.-Even though it says 24 hours of battery life, take it with a grain of salt. The fact is, the higher the volume you play, the more battery it consumes because it uses more power in the drivers and woofers to push out bass and sounds. So, don‚Äôt complain too much if you see faster drainage than advertised, lol. I play around 60%-70% volume range and very bass heavy songs. so I get about 6 1/2 hours from what I observed. Yours might vary.-The biggest critique I have is that it‚Äôs the worst-sounding speaker if you go above 80% volume. The distortion and fuzzy sound are awful. The higher the volume, the less bass you‚Äôll hear, and the highs and mids kick in instead. To be fair, most small speakers are like this anyways. The best volume range I found is 30%-70%, especially 60%, which produces the most balanced bass and highs.In conclusion, if you want a small yet sleek speaker with great sound, then this is for you.By the way, don‚Äôt even compare this to the JBL Charge 5. It literally has different usage, and the size difference is there, lmao. A bigger and more expensive speaker can push out more sound and bass, LMAO. So yeah, it‚Äôs kind of like comparing apples to pears, lmao. I only say this because so many people compare this to the Charge 5 or other bigger speakers.
timestamp: Reviewed in the United States July 1, 2024
product_attributes: Color: Matte BlackStyle: PillPattern: Without AppleCare+

title: 5.0 out of 5 stars The Pill punches far above it's weight class!!
author: Brian Severn
content: Beats Pill (2024) is a high quality product, from the Apple'esque packaging, to the incredible sound output from this small [tiny?] Bluetooth speaker. Incredibly easy to use, connect via Bluetooth and your off to the races.This speaker is about the diameter of a Coke can, albeit longer. It has a pre-attached teather that seems strong enough. Claims to be IP67 water resistant. It comes with a small instruction manual and a USB-C charging cable (USB-C YAY!!!). They claim the battery life is 24 hrs, and it may well be as we've been evaluating it for about a week off and on every day and it's still going strong.I tested it via Bluetooth, mainly streaming via Apple Music, and or it's size it packs quite a punch! Decent mids and highs, and it has bass! Not tons of bass [expected for it's size, it's just physics), but it's decent, if not exceptional given the size of this, but that is expected of any Beats branded speaker product, and this one doesn't disappoint! Another neat feature is that it allows the pairing to two Pill units for stereo music. It's easy to control, there are four buttons: power button, multi-function button (play/pause/next/previous), volume down, and volume up.I really like It also has a built-in mic so you can use it as a speaker phone as well, and it works pretty good.In summary, for the price, compared to other "party" speakers around the same price class, the Pill punches far above it's weight class, feature sound clarity with decent bass, lots of volume, and simplicity in design as we've come to expect from Beats. While maybe not the cheapest "party" speaker out there, it is among one of the best, if not the best, in it's price class.
timestamp: Reviewed in the United States July 13, 2024
product_attributes: Color: Statement RedStyle: PillPattern: Without AppleCare+

title: 5.0 out of 5 stars Beats is BACK!
author: Justin
content: Look, don't tell Dr. Dre this but I really wanted a new Beats Pill as my dedicated shower speaker. Just something I can set on the shelf by the shower and jam out to without worrying about it getting wet. I misplaced my old one years ago and I always liked the pill shaped form factor.Fast forward to 2024, and we have a brand new Beats Pill that is redesigned from the old model. You still get the pill shape, but now there's some nice updates like the lossless type C listening, improved bass drivers and larger battery capacity...about of days worth of Beats now!The packaging and design are definitely exquisite...it is an Apple product, and it shows in the design and style. There's support for both Apple and Android too which is nice.Sound quality is superb as expected too. Sharp highs and nice thick, booming bass. It definitely leans to a heavier bass sound, which is fine as the end result is still really balanced and crisp.The verdict? A triumphant return for the Beats Pill üî•

title: 5.0 out of 5 stars HUGE audio punch in a small package - just what you expect from Beats!
author: Brett
content: Beats has long been popular for producing audio products - headphones, earbuds, speakers and so on - with great sound that are loud and pack a punch in the form of "boosted" bass notes. In that case, this new Pill wireless speaker is more of the same great recipe. In a fairly compact form factor you get a Bluetooth speaker (it can connect with any Bluetooth device though the documentation is focused rightfully on what most people will do - either Apple or Android phones) that gets VERY loud with VERY rich/boosted bass. The audio is also clear for things like spoken word, so that's a positive overall.Outside of that, the Pill is water resistant (not waterproof, so don't drop it in the pool or leave it out in a thunderstorm, but it's okay - probably - if it gets splashed a bit or drizzled on somewhat - meaning that it's great for outdoor parties given the volume) and has solid battery life. I do like that it can act as a portable battery bank, charging phones if you need to. It's not the primary function, but it's nice to see manufactures add value-added extra functionality that doesn't require any extra accessories or things to carry along. The Pill appears to be very well-built and should prove quite durable. As an added bonus, all the packaging is recyclable - kudos to Beats on that!So if you like your music loud and bass heavy, then this is the wireless speaker for you. If that's the case, give it a try today!

title: 3.0 out of 5 stars Sounds good. Not overly loud. Needs more buttons
author: Carpe_Diem
content: This Bluetooth speaker is on the higher end of the price range for a small form factor speaker.Priced similarly to the JBL Extreme 2 (which I also have) the sound quality is about the same. Which is to say, very good for a small speaker.Compared to the JBL, the Beats Pill is:Not as loudHas a slightly better sound quality.Slightly smallerDoes not have a carrying strap (which you can also use to hang the speaker)Pairs automatically with Apple devices and can be tracked using Find MyBoth offer multiple speaker pairing.My biggest complaint about the Pill is that there are just not enough buttons. There is no dedicated power button, and in fact there are no instructions anyplace in the Apple/Beats ecosystem that tell you how to turn it off. (Push the Action button for more than 1, but less than 1.8 seconds.... how dumb is that?) With only 4 buttons, there are too many button sequence combos to remember. Seriously, a volume up/down AND a track up/down would have made life so much easier.All in all, this is a nice sounding Bluetooth speaker, with some good features, let down with a dumb user interface. If you don't mind learning a few tricks to use this device it will be great.However, if you are one of those people who doesn't read instructions, get something that is more intuitive to use.

content: You may have trouble getting this to play sound from you desktop computer, as I did. The unit misleads you by saying you need to download the app 'Bose connect'. I tried to, but could not get it to download from the App store or from the Bose website. Other Bluetooth speakers connected automatically for me, so this was a hassle. I tried to chat with the Bose help bot, but it was of no help; the lady on the phone at Bose tech support was of no help and disconnected mid-sentence and didn't call me back. I tried to return the item on Amazon, then saw a troubleshooting video. Open your 'systems settings' on your computer and select 'sound'; click the Bose option for speaker 'output'. title: 5.0 out of 5 stars Bose quality
author: Tenkiller
content: Bose has been one of the gold standard in sound for decades. So it‚Äôs not surprising that they pack a lot of quality into this little speaker. For one thing, holds a charge a long time! And it announces each time it‚Äôs turned on how much charge is left. No guessing. The sound quality is really decent for the size of the speaker. It can get very, very loud, if that‚Äôs your thing. It has a bass booster that I usually leave on. I appreciate that it is water resistant as I take this into the bathroom, the kitchen, camping, etc. It paired readily with my iPhone. There are some other features I haven‚Äôt played with yet, like doing my Teams meetings with it using the onboard mic, but I suspect it will be fine. If you are looking for a reasonably small Bluetooth speaker with a big sound without breaking the bank, give it a try.

content: I purchased this because water broke my old Bose Revolve+. I don‚Äôt consider myself an audiophile, but I do listen to music religiously ‚Äî 100k+ hours annually ‚Äî and I can appreciate a crisp sounding speaker with nuance. This speaker lacks the nuance. It‚Äôs not terribly loud in my opinion, even on full volume in my small apartment. However, it is durable, and I love that it‚Äôs waterproof. Upon further research, I discovered that Bose is actually NOT worth the value for the money ‚Äî many audiophiles recommend purchasing from another brand, as these speakers can be made for less than $50 and sold for $400+. Initially I purchased the Bose Soundlink MAX and another Flex (product listed here) as well, in hopes of amplifying the sound as well as achieving stereo sound in my apartment.After doing some research, I returned the Soundlink Max and one of the Flex speakers as well. I purchased some ELAC speakers instead for HOME use, and kept one of the Bose Flex speakers for shower use and traveling, as I spend a lot of time on the beach and this is dust and drop resistant. I purchased this on Prime Day for $99 before tax. I would NOT say it‚Äôs worth $150 full price. The battery is not great. I can leave it charging overnight and it dies with moderate use before the day is over. Mediocre in performance overall.It‚Äôs worth nothing that when I purchased the Soundlink Max from Amazon, the box itself clearly states that the speaker comes from Bose ‚ÄúRETURNS AND REPLACEMENTS.‚Äù I believe the speakers sold on sale are probably speakers that were defected or returned by other customers. Keep that in mind!

title: 5.0 out of 5 stars Simply great.
author: Jake
content: I have thoroughly enjoyed my entire ownership of this speaker.Time of writing this review is roughly 8 months after purchase, having used this speaker practically every single day since. This was a replacement for a very well-loved but somewhat lacking B&O (P3?) oval-shaped speaker that inspired of few of my must-have features.My key requirements in purchasing a speaker at this price point were:- Punchy, solid bass, with high accuracy, clear playback throughout most of the volume range- Relatively attractive, understated, simple design with ergonomic and intuitive controls- Easily oriented for high quality playback in a variety of different situations (facing sideways, upwards, at angles)- Long-lasting battery without any obnoxious constant playback interruptions informing you of battery life remainingThis speaker delivers on all of these.The bass is incredibly clear, with no horrible warbling and distortion that‚Äôs very common with dozens of other similar speakers. The audio playback is very crisp and clear, with no noticeable quality losses. I‚Äôm sure it‚Äôs not perfect, but it‚Äôs more than adequate for 95%+ of people. Even at low volumes, the quality is still extremely high. There is a usable, enjoyable sound at every volume level.The design is simple, but handsome. It does not look obnoxious or out of place anywhere. It is just the right size, not too large to pop into a bag, and not too small as to have low-power drivers with poor sound. Very easy to transport. The squared design makes it very stable on most surfaces, but is still rounded enough not to get caught on things. The controls are very easy to understand, even the multi-device Bluetooth cycling and syncing. I have no complaints.The speaker works well for playback in nearly any position, especially when placed on a table or other nice playback surface. It can be placed facing upward, and the speaker enhances playback for all-around sound. When placed horizontally, the same happens for directional playback. Very impressive stability in a wide variety of situations. Some would consider the lack of a lanyard or string to be a downside for this point, but there is massive benefits to keeping this speaker on a surface.The battery life is incredible. Vastly longer than I had really expected for this speaker. With my personal usage (middle volume range, 2-3 uses a day for 30 to 60 minutes at a time), I usually recharge every 1-2 weeks. Not sure what exactly that equates to in real playback time, but I still find it impressive. The speaker will notify you at 20% and 10% battery level, which is exactly what I wanted. Many other speakers will interrupt playback at 75%, 50%, etc. I‚Äôve not experienced any noticeable battery decay during my ownership, but I have only fully depleted and nearly fully recharged the entire time, with no ‚Äúfilling up‚Äù in between.Downsides do exist, but most are inconsequential for me.- The audible indicators that inform you of which device you are connected to can sometimes feel a bit sluggish, especially with long device names.- I feel the price point is still a bit on the high side for the value, but I feel I‚Äôve more than gotten my money‚Äôs worth. I just like a good deal.- Volume occasionally spikes very high in certain scenarios when switching between devices, but is fairly easily turned down after a quick scare.I would highly recommend this speaker to anyone in the market for a speaker at this price point. This is an especially good deal on sale. If you‚Äôre still reading at this point, just get the damn thing on the way.
timestamp: Reviewed in the United States May 4, 2024

title: 5.0 out of 5 stars A premium speaker in a sturdy package.
author: Reviewer MHM 3-5
content: I bought this speaker because I wanted a way to listen to music while grilling in my backyard. I had no expectations of it being a ‚Äúparty‚Äù speaker or anything of the like.But my goodness. This speaker punched above the weight I expected and what reviewers claim. They say it‚Äôs good for less than 10 people. Probably true if in an enclosed space.Outside, standing in the corner of my backyard about 40+ feet away, the speaker volume is at about 60-70% and with the air conditioner droning on I can still hear this speaker, and the vocals are clear, the instruments are clear, and there‚Äôs even some punch of the bass. It‚Äôs so much more potent than I expected.I actually bought a second one (the one pictured) so I could utilize Party Mode and Stereo Mode, and then these are far better than they have any right to be. The bass shook through the house at about 40% volume, to the extent that my wife actually asked me to return one and get some noise cancelling headphones if I wanted to be blaring music all day. üòÇSo (for now), I‚Äôm obliging and returning one, but honestly, I don‚Äôt want to. One of these speakers are great. Two make a great portable stereo system.Now for the feature set. Key selling points for me were:1. Durability. It‚Äôs made of steel and silicone, is rated to withstand a dunk in water and dust. You can enjoy this in the yard, on your workbench, swimming, shower, etc. I live in high desert, and the wind blew over these speakers from a table to the ground and they didn‚Äôt have a single dent or scratch. Which leads me to‚Ä¶2. The device has sensors built in that detect its positioning, so the sound quality was maintained even if it‚Äôs on its back, side, or face down. None of the other products that compete in this segment offer that function to my knowledge.3. Unlike other products that I considered, this sounded good right out of the box. Anker (Soundcore) offers some great competition in this segment, but needs the EQ tweaked to shine. They‚Äôre not bad by any means, but I wanted things to just be simple. Power on and go without fuss. Bose delivered that.There are similar products for sure. Ultimate Ears will also let you pair two portables to create a stereo, but it lacked the intelligence that this speaker did.We already covered Soundcore. Tweak with the EQ, save some money, you‚Äôll likely be happy.These speakers do often go on sale, and I purchased mine used (like new) and refurbished respectively. The ‚ÄúUsed‚Äù unit was actually brand new from Amazon, broke the seals on the box and everything. Far as I could tell, the speaker just rolled around in someone‚Äôs trunk unopened before returning. The box had some cosmetic damage but no dents, broken seals, and all accessories were obviously also unopened.Refurbished unit came straight from Bose. Also came with all accessories and literature, just a box that was labeled ‚ÄúRefurbished‚Äù. Warranty on refurbished or new are 1 year regardless.I bring this up to encourage you to save some money, reduce some e-waste, and buy secondhand like I did. No judgments if you want to go new of course! But I got 2 speakers, one that was new in reality, essentially $100 off the set, and I didn‚Äôt miss out on anything in terms of product or warranty.$150 is pricey for a speaker, but $103 for a Bose speaker is not. Especially one that can literally go for a swim.Four criticisms I‚Äôd like y‚Äôall to know. First, compression above about 75% volume. Your bass will flatline above this point to maintain clarity of the track as a whole. In reality, that just means you go from a slightly warm tone to a very neutral tone of sound profile. No big deal unless you‚Äôre blasting EDM, Hip-Hop, the like. As I said, this little 20W speaker carries enough punch that 70% was more than enough to fill my backyard.Second criticism is no biggie for me, but worth bringing up for those shopping the competition. I didn‚Äôt want to fuss with an EQ, but competitors do have them to fine tune your sound. Consequentially, the app is basically useless beyond seeing your battery life and an option on how to do party mode (not required).Third criticism is truly a nitpick, but why do I have two apps for my Bose products? Why do I need one for headphones and one for speakers? Wish Bose would put all their portable speakers and headphones into one app. You could easily knock out criticisms 3-4 by just putting this speaker into the Bose Music app, like my QuietComfort Headphones, and this VERY speaker's big brother, the Soundlink Flex Max, is already there. Why the heck is the Soundlink Flex not in Bose Music, with a basic EQ like the others?Fourth, this uses outdated Bluetooth. No big deal. Pairs easily. But don‚Äôt expect to watch movies or game off of this. Latency is too high.Anyhow, enough of that. Go buy one. Or better yet, two. You won‚Äôt be disappointed.

title: 4.0 out of 5 stars Small speaker, big sound, travel friendly

content: Got this lil thing for Prime Day for only $99. I‚Äôm not going to lie, I had low expectations and planned on returning it. After opening it and setting it up, I got to see what the hype was about. Took me a couple hours of listening to figure out if it was a bang for my buck or a waste of money.I currently have the first UE Megaboom that I use daily that I bought back in 2016. It‚Äôs loud, has bass and can fill a room. Sadly, the charge isn‚Äôt exactly reliable so I was looking for something new. The Bose Link Flex definitely has a great quality sound. It will definitely fill a room. I like to use mine in the shower and acoustically in the shower the bass just sounds amazing!! Speaker actually fell off the shelf from the bass and survived the fall.Now, I listen to just about every genre of music. I found it to sound best with Latin music. Vocals are super clear. When it came to rap music (or music with lots of bass) I found it to sound perfectly balanced when the volume was at about 75%. Above that you‚Äôll definitely still get volume but the bass will take a seat back. I‚Äôm used to the UE Megaboom that has 360 sound. While the Bose Link Flex will fill a room, the sound seems more straight forward depending if you want to stand it up or lay it down.Bose App is decent. Doesn‚Äôt really have any equalizer setting on there if that‚Äôs what you‚Äôre loooking for.I got this because it is small enough to pack in a carry on and not take up too much space in my bag. Might I add, it‚Äôs almost the same size as my iPhone 14 Pro Max . I can easily carry both in one hand. Easy to say, I‚Äôm going to keep this speaker with me. Now let‚Äôs see if the battery life is legit. I‚Äôll check back in.

title: 5.0 out of 5 stars 5 Million Stars!! ‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê
author: Caitriona Gillespie
content: OMG this is the best speaker which is not a huge floor speaker (over 1 foot high) that is part of a massive speaker system. The sound quality is truly impressive for a speaker of any size, & I think that if I bought another one, which I'm seriously considering, it would rival my Kenwood stereo system, which has two floor speakers that are over a foot high each, & the Kenwood amplifier, & the Kenwood 5-CD player. All that stuff is so big that it needs its own cabinet & takes up several feet of floor space. I don't know how the geniuses at Bose have done it, but they have somehow packed all that sound into a speaker less than half the size of a loaf of bread that is also a very appealing shade of lilac that goes with my d√©cor. The Bluetooth connection works perfectly every time, even though I don't have the newest phone out there. I'm so in love with this speaker, the only complaint I have is purely aesthetic & easily fixed- the fabric loop attached to this beautiful lilac speaker is, for some unknown reason, an entirely ridiculous shade of brilliant orange, which clashes hideously with everything. I solved this problem with a dark purple Sharpie marker. That is the only complaint I have. While this speaker comes without any instructions on how to set it up, the set up is so easy, even when you're not a technology person, that I set it up myself with no help in under a minute. I plugged it in, turned it on, turned the volume all the way up- for some idiotic reason, it comes with the volume all the way down- & then turned on the Bluetooth on my phone & had it search for Bluetooth devices. My phone found the speaker very quickly, paired with it without issue, & started playing. One important thing to know is that when you leave the range of the speaker for an extended period of time, like when I leave for work & take my phone with me, the speaker will turn that connection off, so that when I get home & want to use my speaker again, I need to go over to the speaker with my phone & push the power button once. The speaker will say how much battery power is left & that it is now connected to my phone- I don't turn the Bluetooth off on my phone when I leave the house. I recommend turning the speaker all the way up & then controlling the volume through your phone, which is what I do. I think that's the easiest way to do it. One charge of the battery lasts a long time- at least 12 hours, so that part's great as well. Just buy it already, you won't regret it. It'll beat the pants off of all of your other speakers, even if you already have a nice set of Bose speakers.
timestamp: Reviewed in the United States June 15, 2024

title: 4.0 out of 5 stars Surprisingly loud, no EQ controls, few caveats
author: Jacob Teeler
content: Bought this for work (I run a forklift and JBLs just arent loud enough) and was pleasantly surprised by how loud it gets. Sound quality is fantastic at all volume levels, its durable and holds up pretty well to the elements. The battery does genuinely last a full 8-10 hour shift playing constantly. A few things to note however.There are no EQ controls for it. Sound is well balanced but theres no bass boost, treble, no nada built in.The app is unnecessary once you get it set up with your device, really only need it to check the battery. The speaker will tell you what its battery percentage is if you turn it off and on though.Max volume is entirely dependent on the device its paired to. If i pair it to my PC, max volume is pretty quiet. If i pair it to my buddy's phone it gets pretty loud, but nowhere near as loud as it is paired to my phone.Volume controls are independent from the device and speaker. You can turn your speaker volume to max but your device is the primary control. So if you have the speaker on low volume and your phone all the way to the max, it wont be as loud as both at max, and vice versa. Its very odd.It does not remember the bluetooth volume of the device its paired to, so if you turn it off and use it the next day, it has a habit of being at full blown volume by default. Just be mindful.Other than that, its excellent and no one will be disappointed by it.

title: 5.0 out of 5 stars Returned Charge 5's and bought these
author: Christo
content: THE FOLLOWING IS A REVIEW I LEFT FOR THE CHARGE 5 SPEAKERS. THE COMPARISON WITH THE CHARGE 4 IS AT THE UPDATE NEAR THE END OF THE REVIEW!-------------------I purchased two of these to work as a stereo pair in my apartment to obtain a nice full sound without having to really crank the volume to have an enjoyable experience and bother the neighbors.Well it all started out great, the white look clean and are small enough to not take up too much visual space. They also sound fantastic for a battery powered speaker, relatively full low end and crisp highs without needing to be EQed. They are setup roughly 15‚Äô feet from one another in opposing corners of my studio space. They add presence and a fullness that I was missing from my Notabrick Bluetooth speakers.Now for THE PROBLEMS:I synced the speakers together and switched them to ‚Äústereo‚Äù mode from the app with no problem using my iPhone 13 Pro running Bluetooth 5.1. When it was time to connect it to my stationary media hub it was intended for (a 2020 iPad 8th gen) it would only connect one speaker and not allow for a party link or stereo link between the two Charge 5‚Äôs anymore. It took my some time of testing and no help from the internet to find out that the Bluetooth 4.2 that the iPad uses means the JBLs could no longer connect in a pair. I figured they had their own connection protocol (perhaps wifi 2.4ghz) for party mode. This shared audio functionality will ONLY work if your device that is sending audio is Bluetooth 5.1.SECOND ISSUE:So I put the iPad aside and would only be using my iPhone for music since that‚Äôs the only way I could get the Stereo mode to function. But after 15-30 minutes of music playback the speakers will disconnect themselves from one another requiring you to manually go to them and reconnect themselves. Every third time or so they will also drop the Bluetooth connection requiring you to ‚Äúforget device‚Äù on your phone and resync Bluetooth to your host Charge 5 and then relink the speakers.This is all to say that if you want to use more than one speaker, even using a compatible Bluetooth 5.1 device that they are extremely finicky. Using a single Charge 5 has proved to be very reliable, sound great and look great. I am an audiophile and have many thousands of dollars in pro audio.The current tested Firmware version is 0.8.6.0 and has not been updated for over a year so this is unlikely to be fixed.UPDATE: I purchased two Charge 4 speakers to run through all the same testing and scenarios as the newer Charge 5 Models and found that with the exception of the occasional dropout and auto reconnection (perhaps once every two hours or so) these have solved all my issues. In fact, having the Aux plug on this model has also meant I can plugin my DJ decks to them when we are at the park and the primary speaker that is being plugged into will duplicate the signal and send it to the second speaker wirelessly with no issues. There is about one second of lag with this setup so the use of my DJ headphones is a requirement, but I love the added functionality. I also find the battery meters to be much more easy to read on the Charge 4. Finally, I do not know if it's because the transmission power of the Bluetooth 4.2 in the Charge 4 over the Bluetooth 5.1 in the Charge 5, but I find that I get a longer transmission range with no dropouts with the older Charge 4 model. On paper this should be backwards but testing 4 independent units in different scenarios have shown this to be recurring findings for me. I have used the 2020 iPad, iPhone 13 pro and Macbook M1 pro and a HD Firestick as my test subjects.I do notice that the Charge 5 has a slight edge in real world testing for maximum volume and clearly has a crisper high end to it where the Charge 4 sounds a little more round but is still very pleasing to the ear. I suggest to save a ton of money and pickup the Charge 4 if you are planning on using them in a multi speaker setup like me.

title: 5.0 out of 5 stars Very happy with this purchase
author: JT
content: Initially, my preference was the Bose Soundlink Mini II with its smooth notes and decent sound quality in a small transportable package; that is, until I heard comparison against a JBL Charge 4 on YouTube. Based on that review and others, I purchased this speaker for its waterproof, multi-connect and sound.Great price: You can buy a Charge 3 direct from JBL for $129 with 12 color options, with price point being on par with Amazon.Sounds great; EXCELLENT better describes it. If you have a Charge 3 there isn't enough improvement to justify buying a Charge 4. The Charge 4 went from two smaller speakers to one slightly larger speaker which improved bass frequency from 65Hz to a deeper 60Hz. When the JBL arrived we conducted our own comparison against a Bose Soundlink Mini II and - Wow. The Charge 4 is much clearer, has better frequency response and has better sound presence in the room. It's a bit larger and heavier than the Soundlink Mini II which might turn some off, but to me; if I'm going to carry any speaker like this then I'm taking the same care and am sure I can find just a little more room.Good packaging but NO INSTRUCTIONS?! Not that charging and setup are all that difficult, but this is my first device that requires USB C, first anything that arrived with ZERO printed information, and rechargeable device that arrived with ZERO anything to charge it with. /// Setup was easy. I bought a USB C cable from the nearest gas station and plugged it in for 3 hours since it came somewhat charged already. Once charged, press the Bluetooth button then connect to your phone or other device. For settings, I always recommend phone volume to be no more than 1/2 to 3/4 volume then using the Charge 4 volume from there. This affords you plenty of up/down volume adjustment remotely from your phone and doesn't task the internal sound processor....this, since it's cheaper to replace/repair a Charge 4 than an expensive smartphone. You and someone else can be Bluetooth paired to this speaker at the same time.Battery Life: The built-in rechargeable Li-ion 7500mAH battery is strong. Not only does it support up to 20 hours of playtime (at lowest setting, and figure 10 hours at half volume), but it will also charge your phone and other devices via the USB port. I strongly suggest buying a protective case for it which will hold your charger, USB C charging cable AND any spare USB cable needed for cell phones.It has the same IPX7 waterproof as a iPhone, Samsung or other higher end smartphone. We place it on the deck without any worries of accidents from fluid spills, big splashes, being left in the rain, or even an accidental swim in the pool. Having that peace of mind alone is priceless.JBL Connect+: With Connect+ you can connect several of these to together for full sound experience. Put 4 in opposing corners of a large room, in different rooms, indoor and outdoors...heck, even in your car if your current stereo or speakers are crap.Bottom line - this being my FIRST Bluetooth speaker ever, and having friends that have made different choices for the speakers they have, I have zero regrets with my purchase after hearing it beside theirs. Bang for buck is spot on. I have excellent sound in a transportable package in a wireless speaker that is rugged, waterproof and allows multiple speakers as well as people to connect. I now proudly own the party favorite speaker for socials, events and private enjoyment. WIN!

title: 5.0 out of 5 stars Amazing Directional Sound!
author: WeirdHarold
content: I did my research, looking for a great speaker to use primarily outdoors while I work on projects in the yard - Gardening, Landscaping etc. I needed 2 main things for me- Battery Life and Good Rich Sound that could be heard wherever I might be working. This Speaker checked off all the correct things, so I took a risk and it did not disappoint!Like other reviews have noted, this has a directional sound. You can hear it far better if you are in front of it than you can from behind it, as the sound becomes rather softened or muffled from behind. This is perfect for what I wanted as I can aim it to the area that I'm working in and the sound is focused directly there. The sound is loud enough to be heard while out in the yard and clear enough that you can understand an audiobook being played. It has great highs, good mids and decent bass - Far better bass than I was expecting and the best bass I've ever heard out of a portable speaker. Will it keep us with a full sized Sub, not a chance, but it sounds amazing for it's size! The battery life is absolutely a game changer, every other portable speaker I've ever owned would require me to charge it at least once a day if I used it for most of a day while in the yard. I've been on vacation now for 9 days and I've been using it an average of 4 hours a day and it still shows 3 out of the 5 dots on the battery meter on the front.I do not regret this purchase one bit and would suggest it to anyone looking for a great speaker.
